text: Close on a finger pressing the "record" button of a circa 1970's tape recorder.

This is Harvey Milk speaking on Friday November 18th. This is to be played only in the event of my death by assassination... REVEAL: HARVEY MILK, 48, sitting at his kitchen table in cluttered San Francisco apartment.
During one of the early campaigns, I started opening my speeches with the same line and it sort of became my signature...
In street clothes, trying to corral an angry mob on City Hall's steps, Harvey lifts a bullhorn.
Hello, I'm Harvey Milk, and I'm here to recruit you.
Harvey at his kitchen table making his recording...
If I was speaking to a slightly hostile or mostly straight audience, I'd try to break the tension with a joke...
Harvey is in a plain, ill fitting brown suit making a CAMPAIGN SPEECH to a crowd of stone faced UNION BOYS.
I know, I know, I'm not what you were expecting, but I left my high heels at home. Harvey gets a LAUGH from the AUDIENCE. 2.
RETURN TO: Harvey speaking into his tape recorder.

I fully realize that a person who stands for what I stand for - an activist, a gay activist - becomes the target or potential target for a person who is insecure, terrified, afraid or very disturbed themselves...

POLICE OFFICERS AND PRESS RACE THROUGH THE HALLS of City Hall, their walkie-talkies squawking. Something terrible happened. It's chaos. A STRETCHER IS WHEELED OUT OF AN OFFICE. On it, a FILLED BAG with a WHITE SHEET draped over it. The press rush to get a shot. The police officers quickly load the body onto the elevator and disappear from sight.
A shell shocked DIANNE FEINSTEIN, 45, wades into a throng REPORTERS. Those surrounding her try to quiet the crowd.

As President of the Board of Supervisors, it's my duty to make this announcement. Both Mayor Moscone and Supervisor Harvey Milk have been shot... and killed. GASPS from the REPORTERS. Dianne struggles to be heard.
Police are looking for a suspect... Supervisor Dan White.

The very picture of loveliness, MARY-ANN WHITE, 28, finds husband DAN WHITE, 31, sitting in the pews praying. He's handsome, devout, all-American man in a three-piece suit. She sits by him. A weight hangs. He can't make eye contac

Something has happened. 3. She puts her arm around him, feels a gun at his side. She holds him, firmly gripping the revolver in his holster, t conceal, to keep him from using it, potentially on himsel
RETURN TO: Harvey speaking into his tape recorder...

Knowing that I could be assassinated at any moment, I feel it's important that some people should understand my thoughts. I think that-- (pauses, not sure what to say) I wish I had time to explain everything I did. Almost everything that was done was done with an eye on the gay movement.
CLEAN WHITE LETTERS ON A BLACK SCREEN READ aMILK"

TITLE: "New York City. 1970." HARVEY, 40, is HEADING UP THE STAIRS from the subway platform. He is wearing a SUIT, but he's less than clean His hair is brushing past his ears. HARVEY'S VERY INTERESTED POV: SCOTT SMITH, 22, a sexy cur haired hippie in tight jeans and boots, is HEADING DOWN T THE STAIRS. Harvey tries to make eye contact.
Hey. I'm Harvey.
(so what?) Okay, Harvey...
Today's my birthday. (Scott laughs) No, today is actually my birthday. Well, tonight. At midnight.
Really? 4.
And, believe it or not, I don't have any plans. People took me out after work...
(looking him over) Work? So, that would be... Let me guess. Ma Bell or AT&T.
The Great American Insurance Company. I'm part of the big, evil, corporate establishment that, let me guess, you think is the cause of every evil thing in the world from Vietnam to diaper rash.
You left out bad breath. Falling for it, Harvey covers his mouth. Scott laughs. Th both smile, realizing they share a wry sense of humor. A TRAIN IS COMING, Harvey has to work fast.
So... You're not going to let me celebrate my birthday all by myself are you?
(gently teasing) Listen, Harvey, you're kind of cute for a suit... But I don't do guys over forty.
Well then, I'm in luck.
How's that?
Because I'm still thirty-nine... (showing Scott his watch) And it's only eleven-fifteen.

IN A TIGHT TWO-SHOT, Scott is pressed against a wall with Harvey pressed against his back having sex. Harvey is the aggressor, completely uninhibited. 5. OPERA MUSIC PLAYS on a record player. (Wagner's Tristan a
Harvey feeds Scott spoonfuls of CREAM PIE from a TRAY FUL FOOD that rests on the bed between them. Ice cream, cooki milk, berries... It's over the top and adorable.
Where are you from?
Jackson, Mississippi.
Well, this isn't Jackson, but you still can't respond to every strange man you meet on a subway platform. It's too dangerous.
Now you tell me.
There's nothing tougher than a New York City cop. They're arrogant, and they're everywhere. I'll show you the cruising spots, if you want, if you promise you'll be careful... little Scottie-san.
Are you on uppers or what?
No. This is just... plain old me.
You're afraid of the cops?
I'm just discreet. I know a lot of people here. If they found out, I could lose my job.
(meaning a closet case) Oh. You're one of "those." (examines Harvey's eyes) I think you need a change of scenery. New friends. 6.
I need a change.
(looks at the clock) You're forty now.
(just the truth) Forty years old and I haven't done a thing I'm proud of.
(re: the desert tray) You keep eating like this and you'll be a fat ass by fifty.

(laughs it off) No. Don't you worry. I won't make it to fifty. Scott distracts him, playful, like a newlywed at a weddin he rubs a slice of pie in Harvey's face. Harvey reacts. Wipes the pie from his eye, and tackles hi young, frisky new lover. They kiss. The mess getting everywhere. Harvey brushes it out of Scott's hair.
(an idea, half-jokingly,
Why don't we run away together?
Where to?
RETURN TO: Harvey speaks to the tape recorder. (Throughou the film, these scenes should feel intimate, as if Harvey telling us things no one else knows.)
In those days, San Francisco was the place where everyone wanted to go... To drop out... To fall in love...
8MM HOME MOVIE MONTAGE of Harvey and Scott DRESSED FULL-O LIKE HIPPIES, long hair, beard, beads, sunglasses, drivin 7. through the redwoods, over the Golden Gate Bridge, and in San Francisco.
But by 1972, The Haight was boarded up. Crime-filled. Drug-filled. The new place for us refugees was this run down Irish Catholic neighborhood in Eureka Valley. Six blocks square... The Castro.
Harvey lifts a Nikon camera and starts SNAPPING PHOTOS of Castro Street.

a LIQUOR STORE, empty buildings, boarded windows... Harvey points the camera toward The MARQUEE of the Castro Theater, big letters spelling out... "C A S T R O..." Harvey points his camera across the street at the gray- haired, OWNER of a liquor store. Harvey snaps PHOTOS of h face, an expression of distrust. Harvey SNAPS a SIGN in the liquor shop window that reads:

Harvey's CAMERA focuses on TWO CUTE, YOUNG, HIPPIE BOYS WALKING PAST, one puts his arm over the other. To Harvey' eyes it's a very new site. It's overt. Thrilling. Harvey snaps a photo of an empty storefront with a FOR RE SIGN hanging out front.
The place is FILLED with OPERA MUSIC from a record player Harvey is loading a roll of film into his camera. Scott is getting high, lying in the sun that pours throug the large, empty windows.
I cashed my last unemployment check yesterday...
Well, I hope you did something useful with it.
I bought an ounce of pot. I was just wondering if you had any (MORE)
plans, or thoughts... About us doing something to, you know, bring in an income.
Don't move. Harvey straddles Scott. He begins SNAPPING PHOTOS of him.
I suppose I can wait tables.
No way. I want you right here with me... Did you see place downstairs is for rent?
Yeah.
I was thinking we could open a shop together.
What kind of shop?
One with very little overhead. Not too much work... A little one, just like Morris and Minnie Milk of Woodmere, New York...

Harvey's empty store front has been converted to a CAMERA STORE (with a few, not very impressive, products). Harvey is out on the sidewalk directing Scott who is insi the store's large window hanging a sign: "CASTRO CAMERA."
Just a little to the left... The old liquor store owner from earlier, MCCONNELLY, cros the street to watch. Harvey gives him a warm welcome:
Hello there. I'm Harvey Milk.
You're the new renters?
Yes. Welcome to Castro Camera. 9. Harvey extends his hand. McConnelly shakes, but is wary.

I want to join the, um... What is it? The Eureka Valley Merchant's Association. I want to help in any way possible. I'm no interloper. A Jew perhaps, but I hope you'll forgive that. McConnelly looks from Harvey to Scott in the window.
I don't think your application will be approved, Mr. Milk. This is a family neighborhood. Your kind are far more welcome on Haight street.
(trying to keep it friendly) What "kind" do you mean, sir?
(not playing along) The Merchant's Association will have the police pull your license if you open your doors.
Based on what law?
There's man's law and there's God's law in this neighborhood and in this City. The San Francisco Police force is happy to enforce either.
(to McConnelly as he walks away) Thanks for the warm welcome to the neighborhood!
We pay taxes you know! Harvey grabs Scott's hand... keeps him from heating up, f pouncing. It's not the time for them to bite yet.

location: HARVEY AND SCOTT'S APARTMENT ABOVE THE STORE

text: Scott is sitting on the bed, while Harvey is TALKING A MI MINUTE FROM THE KITCHEN, totally energized. 10.

We'll form our own business association! Start with the gay- owned businesses... We'll take down the addresses of every customer that comes in for a roll of film. We'll ask them what they want to see done here... what they want changed... We'll get money rolling into this neighborhood. Revitalize it...
Can I come in now?
One more minute! (back to his new scheme) I'll go to the neighborhood banks. They must have some gay customers.

Harvey. What's with all this political activist crap? I thought you were a goddamn Republican. Harvey walks into the small dining room holding two plate food. He sets them out on a small dining room table, stil rambling on to Scott in the bedroom.
I'm a businessman, Scott. I think businesses ought to treat their customers right. Even their gay customers. For God's sake, this is San Francisco!
Harvey. It's just like every other city in this country. People hate us. Big surprise.

We should have at least one block in one city right? Start there and take over the neighborhood. (a smile) Okay, you can come in now! Scott heads toward the kitchen. The table is LAID OUT wit home-cooked meal, CANDLES and a huge bouquet of FLOWERS.
Wow. This is-- 11. Harvey SMASHES A CREAM PIE into Scott's face. Payback.
Happy birthday! Scott chases Harvey around the apartment, trying to smear some of the CREAM PIE onto him.

The street is shut down for the first ever Castro Street Fair. The crowd is mostly gay, the majority congregate outside Toad Hall bar. ANGLE ON: SOME OF THE OLD-SCHOOL, IRISH LOCALS milling ab eyeing the scene skeptically. Harvey MOVES THROUGH THE CROWD with Scott, shaking hands.
Thanks for the party, Mr. Milk!

Thanks for joining the Castro Village Association! Harvey arrives at A LONG LINE OF GAY MEN winding out of t Irish liquor store (from earlier). He squeezes past them, into the store, leaving Scott outside.
Excuse me gentleman... ladies. (finding the shop owner) Hello! Mr. McConnelly! McConnelly, at the register, is overwhelmed with all the business.
I just wanted to stop in and see how business was doing.
Fine.
So you don't mind all these homosexuals in here, do you? McConnelly grins, uncomfortable. The line of gay men is curious about the hubbub. Point made, Harvey does a 180. 12.

No. No. Just a joke. Mr. McConnelly here loves our kind. Spend away! (to McConnelly) Tell your wife Hello for me. Harvey spots Scott in the crowd and PULLS HIM TOWARD HIM, KISSING HIM ON THE MOUTH. It's quite the show. They step back out onto the street where an Irish band is now playi Gay men watch. Some clap. Harvey grabs Scott and spins hi through a sharp waltz. OFF the pair at home in their new neighborhood.
And people started hanging around our store. Not customers. Activists, kids, folks who needed a home away from home...
A NEW sign goes in the window: "We are VERY open."

A FEW YOUNG MEN are hanging out in the shop, the beginnin of Harvey's entourage. Harvey moves among them, sharing a clipped Sunday cartoon, lecturing them on politics or the arts, and checking out the cute ones.

There was Danny Niccoletta, a cute art student who I'd picked up at Toad Hall. Turns out he was also good at running the Camera Shop... something Scott and I found we had surprising little interest in... ON DANNY NICCOLETTA, young, waif-like, somewhat helpless.
Opera is passe, Harvey. It's about street theater, now.
What you're not getting is the spectacle of it, the bigger than life emotions... Danny jumps up and IMITATES the LARGER THAN LIFE GESTURES an opera diva, making Harvey laugh. 13.

Jim Rivaldo. A great mind. A great wit. A Harvard graduate, which nobody cared about, in those days, in the Castro... including himself. JIM RIVALDO flops down into the vintage dental chair that sits in front of Harvey's desk. He seems to be looking fo something to occupy his keen mind. A sharply dressed youn man, 20s, DICK PABICH, walks up to peek over his shoulder

And somewhere along the line Jim picked up a protege, a cute political kid from Wisconsin... Dick Pabich... And of course there was Dennis Peron, who ran a very popular business with the new kids... DENNIS PERON hands Scott a FREE JOINT.
And on occasion we actually had a real customer. But only occasionally. ACROSS THE ROOM, Scott is waiting on a CUSTOMER, he's out place: straight, gruff, a union man, ALLAN BAIRD, 40s.
Harvey... This guy wants to talk to you.
(approaches Allan) Welcome. What can we do for you?
Hi, I'm Allan Baird. Teamsters representative, and Director of the Coors beer boycott in California.
Everyone, this is Allan Baird. He's a very big deal, so behave yourselves.
I was told you were like the Mayor of the Castro, said you organized the CVA, you might know some people in the bars. 14.
I do have friends in awfully low places, but just so you know, it's not official yet.
What's that?

The Mayor part. I've considered gathering an army of queers to march up to City Hall and secede, but so far the young gays seem more interested in jeeps and jeans. But if I could be of any use, I'm all ears!
We can't get Coors to go union. These guys are like me, they can't be out of work too long. Harvey pulls Allan aside, away from the audience, easing nerves. It's Harvey at his best.
I'm just curious. Are we your first stop or your last?
(clearly his last) It's been a tough one, Mr. Milk.
Well, you seem to have noticed that my kind of people drink a lot of beer. If we're going to fast for your sake, I think we should get to deliver some of it when you win this fight, don't you?
(INCREDULOUS)
Is that what you really want?
And allies. I'll have Coors out of every bar in the Castro by the end of the week. Deal?
(nods, sincere) Thank you Mr. Milk. 15. JUMP TO: Allan is on his way out. Harvey walks back behin the counter to Scott.
No more Coors beer. It's gotta come out of every bar. Gay and straight.
What's he giving you?
Nothing for me. That's a convert.
A convert to what?
The cause.

A STILL PHOTO MONTAGE: Jim, Dick, Scott and Danny get bar owners throughout San Francisco to unscrew their Coors ta throw out their Coors stock, put on "Boycott Coors" butto and tape up "Dump Coors" posters.

I got "my people" to get Coors out of all the Gay Bars. 30 million bottles worth in San Francisco alone. Coors beer immediately fell from number 1. They caved. One week later, union man Allan Baird hired the first ever openly gay union boys to drive Teamsters trucks... We weren't just a group of pansies anymore. We had a neighborhood. We had the unions. And for the first time, we had a little bit of power.
Maybe that was the day someone first called me the "Mayor" of Castro Street. (a knowing grin) Or perhaps I invented it myself.
Harvey, Jim & Dick, Scott, Danny and Dennis debate the me of working within "the system" versus dropping out. Every is talking over each other... 16. A YOUNG GAY MAN runs into the store.
The fucking cops, man, they're up on Castro Street! Toad Hall. Harvey and the guys race out of the store.
Harvey, Scott, Jim, Dick, Dennis run up the street toward of the Castro GAY BARS where POLICE ARE GETTING OUT OF SQ CARS AND APPROACHING CUSTOMERS crowding around the entran

Clear the sidewalk! Some of the GAY MEN move out of the COPS' way but some of them don't move FAST ENOUGH. The COPS start BEATING them. Harvey, Scott and the OTHERS try to break into the crowd, get closer to the fight. To pull the cops off their frien Danny HANGS BACK, snapping PHOTOS of the event. Scott SHOVES his way past the cops. A COP BRINGS HIS NIGH STICK down hard on SCOTT'S HEAD.
Scott sits on the toilet. Harvey rinses blood from a whit washcloth and goes back to cleaning Scott's HEAD WOUND.
...if we had someone in the government who saw things the way we see them, the way the black community has black leaders who look out for their interests--
You're gonna run for Supervisor, is that the idea?
(HALF-JOKING)
I could go right for mayor, but I think I should work my way up to it... You'll be my campaign manager. 17.
(SARCASTIC)
Because I have so much experience in politics.
Politics is theater. It doesn't matter if you win. You make a statement. You say, "I'm here, pay attention to me."
Harvey, you do that every time you cross the street.
Coors looks like it might cave. The union boys will owe me. Imagine if we get their vote... It'll be fun!
Fun? Harvey starts kissing him all over.
We'll make it a spectacle.

Harvey walks down to Market St. with a box. He waves, sha flirts with everyone. His warmest hello is from a gruff U MAN. Behind Harvey, Scott pushes a loaded shopping cart. Harvey sets his box down right beside a SFPD OFFICER. It reads, aSoap Box.a Harvey steps onto it. A crowd forms.

A week ago, Police officers came into our area with covered up badges and sent fourteen of our people to the hospitals, and to jail. The charges, "Blocking a Sidewalk." Like a round girl at a boxing match, Scott parades around blown up PHOTO from his shopping cart: TWO SF COPS DRAGGI GAY MEN INTO A PADDY WAGON.
--Let us have our tax money go for our protection and not our persecution. Worry about gun control and not marijuana control. (MORE)
School supplies, seniors, not what books I read-- Scott displays an old "Muscle Boys" magazine. Harvey does well timed take. A few hoots from the eclectic crowd.

My fellow degenerates, I would like to announce my candidacy for San Francisco City Supervisor! Scott unfurls three hand made "MILK FOR CITY SUPERVISOR" banners that lap over the sides of the shopping cart.

WE SEE SCOTT, DANNY, JIM handing out FLYERS to a variety SF CITIZENS: gay boys, older people, Chinese people, scar straight people, heckling high school boys. Harvey EAGERLY APPROACHES anyone and everyone, shaking ha if they'll let him, reaching out to old people, straight people, gay people, even buttoned down BUSINESSMEN who cr the street to try to get away from him.
Harvey hands out campaign literature to a PASSERSBY.
Public dental care for retired people... Legalize pot, vote Milk. Harvey is distracted. A young, long haired CLEVE JONES passes. At 18, he looks 15. Harvey tries for his attentio
Hey, I like the way your pants fit... Where are you from, kid?
(LAUGHS)
Sorry old man, not interested.
Where's home?
Phoenix.
I'm Harvey Milk. I'm running for Supervisor. What's your name? 19.
Cleve... Jones.
Well Mr. Jones, we should walk up to my camera shop and register you.
Fuck that. Elections of any kind are a bourgeois affectation.
Is that right? Do you trick up on Polk Street?
(only half-joking) If I need the cash... But I'm selective about my clients.
Tell me one thing before you get back to work then. What was it like to be a little queer in Phoenix?
I faked a lung disease to get out of PE. So what? What are you, some kind of street shrink?
Sometimes. But what I'm saying is, Phoenix can change. But we have to start with our street: rent control, police abuse, pot, parks, seniors.
(turns to go) Well, good luck with all that.
You know what I think, Cleve Jones?
That you're gonna get somewhere if you keep talking?
No. That you need to do what you're good at. Be a prick. Fight City Hall. Fight the cops. Fight the people who made you come here to do what you do. 20.

Sorry old man, I'm leaving for Spain tomorrow. Europe. Got all the cash I need in my back pocket. A GROUP OF CLEVE'S FRIENDS shout at him to join them. Har watches him dart across the street to his friends.
I didn't come out until very late in life. There was nobody to--
--look up to, no hope for a better life. Those that did were outcast... arrested.. suicide. And the young ones, who did escape home... and who arrive in San Francisco, and then what...
ANGLE ON: PARAMEDICS placing a BLOODY VICTIM into a BODY
The afruita was walking home with his atricka when they were jumped. REVEAL: Harvey picks a blood stained whistle up off the street, the man's last attempt to call for help.
(from the victim's wallet) Name's Robert Hillsborough. Did you know him?
He used to come into my shop. Are there any witnesses?
Just the "trick." Jerry Taylor.
Jerry wasn't a trick. They were lovers.
Call it what you will. He's our only witness and he says he can't identify the attackers. 21.
There'd be a dozen witnesses if they thought you boys had any real interest in keeping them safe.

You're the Mayor of Castro Street now, right Harvey? You really wanna help? Get your people to show some discretion on the streets, huh? HARVEY'S POV: The PARAMEDICS pull up the zipper on the bo bag. We follow the zipper past the victim's bloody hands, torso, his face.
TO HAND DURING THE FOLLOWING POLITICAL MEETING. (We catch glimpse of the PHOTOS and see naked skin).
Well, it looks like the big guns and the rich gays in San Francisco are going to back Dianne Feinstein and other straight candidates they consider "gay-friendly."
Who cares about those old queens? Scott is laying down on THE BIG RED COUCH.
Why isn't my campaign manager leading the meeting?
I'm beat, Harvey. I passed out flyers for seven hours straight.
In the bathhouse?

(giving it right back) People in bathhouses vote. I'm tired. I'm taking a nap. Scott heads up the stairs to their apartment. A CUSTOMER comes in. Danny quickly gathers the REVEALING PHOTOS and puts them back in the envelope. 22.
Just checking the exposure. That a new boyfriend? He's very cute.
(taking the photos, embarrassed) Um... Thanks, Harvey.

(to Jim) So who are these so-called "gay leaders?" And who appointed them? And what are you suggesting, Jim, that I'm supposed to go and solicit their endorsement? PAST HARVEY WE SEE A GRANDMOTHERLY VOLUNTEER, THELMA, ope the mail, casually reading a letter, then rising and approaching Harvey.
We're down here, on the streets, trying to help people, so where they hell are they?
David Goodstein is the publisher of The Advocate and he has a house--
A mansion--
--in Atherton.
(clearly shaken) Harvey, you should read this. CLOSE ON THE LETTER as it goes from Thelma to Harvey.
Scott reads the LETTER. Harvey sits VERY STILL.
"Harvey Milk will have a dream journey and nightmare to hell, a night of horror. You will be stabbed and have your genitals, cock, balls, prick cut off." (MORE)
(BEAT)
I'm calling the police.
They probably wrote it. (off Scott's anxiety) Hey, If somebody tries to kill me, I'll get the sympathy vote, right? Could be just the push we need.
You think this is funny? Look at it. Reluctantly, Harvey takes the letter from Scott.

It's a complete joke. No rhythm. No humor. It's insulting. CLOSE ON THE LETTER: Someone has drawn a STICK FIGURE of Harvey being tortured - bullets, knives, fire, etc. Harve makes a DECISION: He sticks the DRAWING to the refrigerat the first thing he'll see in the morning.
Don't do that.
If you put it away, hide it in a drawer, it'll just get bigger and scarier. Now it's there. We'll see it every day. It can't get us.
All this energy... to make yourself a target. And what for? Something we have no chance to win. Harvey wraps his arms around him.
I keep telling you, it's not just about winning.
Harvey, in his work boots and jeans, watches as a LARGE G SLIDES OPEN allowing his entry. Scott, even scruffier loo than Harvey, stands next to him.
The "top gays" in San Francisco were David Goodstein and his lawyer sidekick Rick Stokes. David was a (MORE)

rich old queen who'd bought the biggest gay magazine, The Advocate. He had it delivered to subscribers in brown paper bags so no-one would know... That's how he lived his life, covered up, discreet. Harvey and Scott are shown to the pool area by a HOUSE BO Statues and potted plants and expensive marble. Everythin shouts "GOOD TASTE!" Scott strips off his clothes and DIVES INTO THE POOL.

Harvey has lunch with the "gay establishment": DAVID GOODSTEIN, 58, gold and turquoise jewelry, and Goodstein' protAgA, RICK STOKES, 45, reserved. Rick can't keep his eyes off naked Scott in the pool.

I worked for a financial institution. I was very discreet. But someone spotted me at the opera, sitting in a box, next to my lover. And I was fired. That's when I decided to do something. So I bought The Advocate. And I use my money and my influence in quiet ways, to do what I can...
Endorsing straight candidates is what you think is best to help us?
Yes, if they're friendly to our cause.
(DEFENSIVE)
Politics is complicated in San Francisco, and Supervisor is a citywide office. Political alliances need to be built. You can't simply move here from across the country and run for office.
But I am running for office. I'm on the ballot. I have the union rank and file, the seniors, and I could use your magazine's endorsement. 25.
Harvey, we're like the Catholic church. We welcome converts, but we don't make them Pope the same day.
And why haven't you run?
It's too early for a gay candidate for Supervisor. Especially one from the Castro. It's bad for the community's image. Scott climbs out of the pool and sits at the table, naked sopping wet.
What's wrong with the Castro?
Nobody works there. It's all sex and drugs and more sex and no one taking responsibility for their own problems.
The cops come into our neighborhood and beat us. They turn a blind eye if one of us is murdered.
Then we file a lawsuit against the city. We go to our political allies in City Hall...
There are no real gay allies. Yes, our friends may sense our struggle, but they can't feel it. It's not life or death for them. We need our own in office.
You can't demand acceptance overnight.
Why not? How can we ask them to respect us if we don't show ourselves some self respect, David. 26.
The more aouta you make us, the more you incite them. Step back and quiet down.

Go back into the closet? Is that what you're saying? Because I know the closet. I lived in it for more years than I care to remember. (rising to go) I don't need your endorsement. I'm not asking anyone for acceptance. I don't have time to ask.
For you, politics is a game, a lark. Like putting on a rock festival or staging a "love-in." You're too old to be a hippie, Harvey Milk! Harvey turns around, ready for a fight.
I'm not a candidate, I'm part of a movement. The movement is the candidate. There's a difference. You don't see the difference. But I do.
(getting Harvey out) Thanks for the swim. I'm sorry I pissed in your pool.
A SLOW MOTION MONTAGE OF: the citizens of the Castro are turning out to vote. Young, old, gay, straight... but a weight hangs over the day.

When the vote came in on election day... out of 32 candidates vying for 6 seats... We came in 10th. Just a handful short of being the first big eared, gay as a three- dollar-bill, cock sucker ever elected to public office. 27.
So... I went for it again in '75... with just a few... minor... adjustments.

location: SECOND HAND STORE IN THE CASTRO

text: CLOSE ON: Harvey looking through a hole in the bottom of pair of well worn wing-tips. He tries them on anyhow. JUMP TO: Harvey steps out of a dressing room in a brown s His hair is cut short, his face is shaven clean. It's qui transformation. Scott and the old owner, LILY, size him u
No. Not cute. The shoes are hideous and I hate your hair. You're not fooling anybody.
I'm not gonna let the Pacific Heights biddies write me off again because of a ponytail. I like it. Scott is horrified. Harvey pulls a pair of movie ticket s from its inner pocket.
Cabaret? For two? Lily, is this from one of my kind?
No, no. You won't run into the owner. He died in that suit.
This isn't sexy, Harvey. Harvey grabs Scott, kisses him. Then playful:
Too bad. No more pot, no more bath houses for me and little poo.
MONTAGE: More ACTIVITY inside and outside the shop. More VOLUNTEERS. The printing press burns through flyers.
We ran and we lost the Supervisors race a second time in '75, but with (MORE)
more votes than ever. So in 1976, against everyone's advice, I really pissed off the Democratic political power houses, because I ran against "their boy"--

head_text.subj: A SIGN GOES IN THE SHOP WINDOW "HARVEY MILK VS. THE MACHI

text: --Art Agnos, a part of their "Political Machine." And this time we weren't running for City Supervisor. This time it was bigger, California State Assembly.

location: HASTINGS COLLEGE OF LAW / CANDIDATE DEBATE

text: It's a firestorm of words as Harvey debates Art Agnos.
It's a racket. It's 1976 and you still have to be straight, white, Catholic and male to get into the San Francisco police force. It's Racist. Homophobic.
How many people do you consider enemies, Harvey? I've counted five already. Art smiles. Chuckles flutter through the audience.

You're right, Art. And many are your closest friends. You see, I don't think State Assembly seats should be awarded on the basis of service to the Democrat Machine. Machines operate on oil and grease. They're dirty, dehumanizing, and too often unresponsive to any needs but those of the operator.
Mr. Milk, I've worked for years as a social worker in this city. I know Sacramento. I know how to get done what we all need done there.
Tell me Mr. Agnos... right here in the Castro, Robert Hillsbourough was murdered for walking home with his long time partner. Stabbed, (MORE)

fifteen times. The last words he heard were "Faggot, Faggot, Faggot..." And you say you're outraged, but why won't your liberal establishment return our calls? Why won't they bring these murderers to justice?
Art Agnos puts his arm around Harvey as they walk out.
You know Harv', your whole rap's a real downer.
My God, you're handsome up close. I can't tell you how much I'm looking forward to licking you... in the polls.
(LAUGHS)

You talk a lot about what you're against. What are you for? In this town, you gotta give em' a reason for optimism or you're cooked. Art gets into his car and goes. Harvey has no car. He sto and PONDERS ART'S WORDS... They stick with him.

Scott tries to make a simple meal of pasta, struggling to operate in the kitchen that is filled with Harvey's POLIT ENTOURAGE and VOLUNTEERS. He finds Harvey, Jim, and Dick having an impromptu strate meeting in the adjoining bedroom.
Harvey. Dinner.
... get some union boys in the audience, they love me...
I can't control who's in the audience...
Harvey, you need to eat something. Now. 30. Scott steps back into the kitchen.
Ladies and Gentlemen. Our apartment is officially off limits. CHASES the VOLUNTEERS out of the kitchen, out of his bedroom... down the stairs...
Downstairs. Time to go. Go. OUT! Harvey emerges, about to intervene.
Don't say anything. For once, Harvey keeps his mouth shut. Jim and Dick sneak past Scott, sheepishly. When Scott and Harvey are alone..
Sit down and eat. Harvey and Scott eat dinner in tense silence.
If you say one thing about politics or your campaign or where you're speaking tonight or whose endorsement you need... I'll stab you with my fork I swear to God.
I just wanted to say... This is the most delicious meal I've ever eaten in my entire life. Harvey gives a warm smile. Scott gives a laugh, but he lo like he's about to lose it.
If we lose this one, it'll be just me and you again. I promise. Scott nods. That's exactly what he needed to hear.

Harvey walks Castro's streets alone, toward his apartment 31. A CAR PULLS UP BEHIND HARVEY. A MAN jumps out of the car, the driver speeds around the block. Harvey turns a corner The man follows. Harvey picks up his pace. He searches hi pockets for a whistle, a weapon, and beelines it to his s his nerves are failing him. He gets to the doorway of his camera store, and runs face first into: CLEVE JONES. He's not the feisty young kid he on the street earlier. He's been sitting on Harvey's step waiting with wet eyes.
Phoenix? (off Cleve's smile) We should go inside. They do. Harvey locks the door behind them.
Harvey pours two cups of coffee, and delivers one to Clev who is pulled away on the big red couch.
You staying up with me?
The election's tomorrow. I won't sleep... Was he good looking?
No. He was hideous.
Hard to tell what's worse. With me, my boyfriends usually find better looking ones to cheat with.
I thought we were gonna spend the rest of our lives together.
Guess what, Cleve Jones.
What?
You're going to meet the most extraordinary men, the sexiest, brightest, funniest men, and you're going to fall in love with so many of them, and you won't know until (MORE)
the end of your life who your greatest friends were or your greatest love was.
Is that supposed to help?
Maybe a little. Or not.

I went to Spain last month... long story. In Barcelona, there was this memorial march for gay people who died under Franco. The police tried to break it up. It started a riot. A bullet ripped through a drag queens scalp, his wig flew off, but he kept fighting. There was blood literally running in the gutter.
We could have a revolution here too. But you can't just use the Castro to cruise. You gotta fight.
You think you'll win?
Winning isn't my strong suit.
(BRAVADO)
Well, I don't "do" losing. Ever. Maybe I should run for office, and you can work for me. (off Harvey's laugh) If you can do it, I can do it.
Can you assemble a thousand people in an hour?
Yeah, sure.
All right, if I run again, you're my man.
Polls open in 3 hours. Lets hit the bus stops.
Harvey is on the back of a motorcycle. The driver heads u Market Street. Folks stand in voting lines, flags outside polling places. City Hall's tall dome grows nearer.
And we lost that Assembly Race too, which made me a bona fide three- time, political loser.
CLOSE ON THE TV SET PLAYING A 1970's ORANGE JUICE COMMERC featuring runner up to Miss America, ANITA BRYANT.

"Come to the Florida sunshine tree, great tasting orange juice naturally, orange juice with lots of vitamin c, from the Florida sunshine tree." Harvey is alone in the shop, surrounded by remnants of a celebration party that never happened. Jim Rivaldo lets himself into the store. Jim has his maps rolled up under his arm.

(trying to cheer up Harvey) We lost, but we lost by less! More votes than ever... (Harvey fake grins) I remember when that used to work. I want to show you something. This is remarkable. Jim starts laying out his trusty MAPS, color coded with precinct results from that night.

The red is where you did best tonight. If we can get the initiative on district elections to pass, and we can -- we can -- our new Supervisor's District will go right up Market. Right around the Castro. 34. The district Jim outlines is ALL BRIGHT RED.
If you run for Supervisor with this new district, it's a potential landslide. You'll be the first up- front gay man elected to major office in the U.S.
I don't know if I have another one in me. Or Scott. But Harvey's gaze deceives his words. HOLD ON HARVEY - contemplating a FOURTH run for office.

The GROUP gathers around the TV WHICH SHOWS NATIONWIDE NE CLIPS OF ANITA BRYANT celebrating her election victory in Florida (overturning a pro-gay statute). A CHYRON READS: "Landslide defeat for Florida Gay Rights Law."
Tonight the laws of God and the cultural values of man have been vindicated. The people of Dade county, the normal majority, have said enough, enough, enough.

Gays in Florida can now be removed from their jobs and prosecuted if their "deviant" lifestyles are uncovered. HARVEY'S POV OUT A WINDOW: FURIOUS GAYS pour out of the b BLOWING WHISTLES, raising TRASH CANS... It might turn int RIOT.
Gays can't reproduce, so they must recruit young people into their lifestyle...
Bryant, a spokeswoman for the orange juice industry, vowed to (MORE)
bring her campaign to the rest of the country... Harvey's PHONE RINGS. He snatches it up.
Scottie?
I'm sorry sir. I um... I read about you in the paper.
I'm sorry. I can't talk right--
Sir, I think I want to kill myself.
No. You don't want to do that. (BEAT)
Where do you live?
In Minnesota.
You saw me in a paper in Minnesota? How'd I look?
My folks are taking me to this place tomorrow. A hospital. To fix me.
There's nothing wrong with you. Listen to me. You don't have to hurt yourself, okay? Are you there? (only breathing from the other end) Here's what you have to do. Are you listening?
Yes.

Get on a bus. Go to the next biggest city. New York, San Francisco, LA, or even Minneapolis. It doesn't matter. Just leave. (off the boy's tears) You won't be alone. There are people out here just like you who will welcome you and love you. (MORE)
You're not sick. You're not wrong. God does not hate you. Just leave.
I can't.
Yes. You can. Just get on a bus.
I can't... I can't walk, sir. I'm in a wheelchair... Sir. Are you there? Harvey FORCES HIMSELF TO SOUND CALM...

That's okay. It's going to be okay. Over the phone, Harvey hears the SOUND OF AN ADULT VOICE, someone finding the BOY on the phone, then... The LINE goes DEAD. It's all too much for Harvey. There's nothing a speech or a pep talk can do to fix this. Harvey overwhelmed. Dick comes upstairs.
Harvey, you better come down. There's gonna be a riot. Moving in a daze, stunned by the call, Harvey digs out A BULLHORN and heads out.
From inside, SCOTT WATCHES HIS LOVER JUMPING BACK IN THE FREY. A weight hangs. He doesn't follow...
Cleve RUSHES into the bar (ON FIRE WITH RIGHTEOUS FURY) a BLOWS A POLICE WHISTLE to get everyone's attention.
Out of the bar and into the streets! Anita Bryant is coming after you!
Angry young men mill around the streets, their rage build Someone TOSSES a trash can and it ROLLS. A POLICEMAN in riot gear comes up to Harvey. 37.
If you can't control em', we will.
Give me permission to march them.
Where?
Anywhere.
Surrounded by the massive crowd, HARVEY CLIMBS THE LARGE that covers the subway construction at Market and Castro. It's a stage of sorts. Harvey lifts his bullhorn to his l

I know you are angry. I am angry. Follow me through the streets of San Francisco to share our anger! Harvey jumps down and begins walking, not sure if the mob will follow. Finally, they do. Cleve catches up.
Are they following in back?
Yes. Where are we going?

I don't know. (off Cleve's concern) We have to keep them moving. Exhaust them. March them till they drop. We can't have a riot tonight. Harvey LIFTS THE BULLHORN. He starts a marching chant. Th crowd starts following along. JUMP TO: Gays glare at cops. Cops beat their nightsticks against their chests and power poles. Anger burns as Harv marches the mob toward City Hall. Dick and Jim catch up.
They're still too hot in back. They'll burn the joint down.
Help me turn them up Van Ness. We'll go all the way to Broadway. 38. Dick heads back to try and wrangle the crowd. Harvey continues marching.

Harvey arrives, the crowd still hot. Cops beat their nightsticks against their shields. Some jab protesters, trying to incite a fight. Anger burns. Harvey climbs the steps, his stage. He lifts his bullhorn
My name is Harvey Milk... And I want to recruit you. The CROWD ROARS APPROVAL.

I am here tonight to say, we will no longer sit quietly in our closets. We must fight. Not just in the Castro, or San Francisco, but everywhere the Anitas go. Anita Bryant did not win tonight. Anita Bryant has brought us together... She is going to create a national gay force! (The crowd ROARS) And the young people in Richmond, Minnesota, or Jackson, Mississippi, or Woodmere, New York... Who are coming out and hearing Anita Bryant on television telling them that they're wrong, they're sick, that there is no place for them in this great country, in this world... They're looking to us for something tonight... (his big moment, realizing his true mission) And I say, we have to give them hope! The CROWD goes WILD. HARVEY'S SPEECH CROSSES THE CUT TO..
Harvey speaks to the "PARENT-TEACHERS UNITED FOR BETTER SCHOOLS" group.
--Hope for a better world... Hope for a better tomorrow... Hope for a (MORE)
better place to come to if the pressures at home are too great...
Harvey speaks to a hall filled with TEAMSTERS.
Hope for the worker who awakens from the American dream to find that all the jobs have left the country... We gotta give em' HOPE! PAN FACES OF TEAMSTERS - Several MINORITY FACES. CLOSE ON

head_text.subj: ALLAN BAIRD, (UNION LEADER OF THE COORS BEER BOYCOTT)
STARTS TO APPLAUD. OTHERS JOIN IN.

text: (pre-lap, an intimate tone) When San Francisco changed the voting rules--
Harvey is still speaking into the tape recorder...

--they allowed people to elect Supervisors directly from their own neighborhoods. A black neighborhood could elect an African- American. Chinatown could elect a Chinese Supervisor... And the Castro could choose me or Rick Stokes. But decent art begs for balance, right? So little district 8, two miles south of The Castro--
CAMERA MOVES ALONG THE STREET catching glimpses of church shops and tidy houses.
--promised to stay the same as ever. Conservative, Irish, Catholic and with just the right touch of poetry, they found themselves a handsome ex-cop.
DAN WHITE holds a small press conference. His words are fiery, but his delivery and stage presence are lacking. 40.

I'm not going to be forced out of San Francisco by splinter groups of social radicals, social deviants, and incorrigibles. You must realize there are thousands upon thousands of frustrated, angry people such as yourselves waiting to unleash a fury that will eradicate the malignancies which blight our beautiful city.
Harvey's suit is laid out. A record turns. Wagner blasts the windows. Scott is folding his clothes into a box.
Evelyn Lear's in town, at the Opera house in Tannhauser.
Clearly.
What if she strolls into the Castro for a cocktail? (Scott keeps packing) Just one more. We can't let Rick Stokes take it.
Let Rick have it. Nobody thinks you're a fraud here, Harvey. You're not in New York, you're not a closet case asshole anymore. People respect you here. Relax for a year. Get us back on our feet.
If people are ever going to take me seriously, I have to win this one.
Since when did you care if anyone took you seriously?
Anita wants to put us all back in concentration camps. Rick Stokes is too weak to beat her back if she gets to California. I have to be in office to protect us from them. 41.

I can't do another one. (Harvey says nothing) I'll be back for my sheets. If you're not here, I'll see you in the shop next week. Scott picks up his box of clothes and starts out of the apartment. Harvey, not meaning a word:
If you leave me right now... I can find someone new.
I know. You're a catch. Scott leaves. Harvey is in shock, unable to comprehend th loss. Unable/unwilling to reverse the choice he's made.
The ENTOURAGE is completely caught up in the new campaign (Cleve, Jim, Dick, and newcomer MICHAEL WONG, 23, asexual devoutly political). Harvey is RANTING, ripping down an Assembly campaign poster.

--Ring out the old, ring in the new. This is over. Done. I don't want to see anything that say's fucking Assembly. This three-time loser faggot is running for Supervisor goddamn it! ANNE KRONENBERG, 23, parks her motorcycle outside, WALKS THE CAMERA SHOP, and plants herself behind HARVEY'S DESK. Cleve, Mike, Jim and Dick are STARING at Anne.
Who the heck is she?
(suddenly cool) Our new campaign manager. She called last week to volunteer and I asked her to help.
Help or take over? What about Scott?
We need new blood. (introducing them) (MORE)
Guys... Anne Kronenberg. (Off their puzzled looks) She's a woman... A woman who likes women. Odd, isn't it?
Hi guys. Mr. Milk... Rick Stokes isn't pulling out. He's officially filed to run against you. My friend at The Advocate says David Goodstein is backing him.
A gay candidate against a gay candidate. It's unfortunate.
They'll split the gay vote. The straights will divide and conquer.
Try to find out when they're going to announce.
You replaced Scott with a lesbian?
Anne worked on a recycling campaign up North. She's very organized.
How do you know she's not a plant from Rick Stokes' campaign?
Are you guys always this paranoid?
Yes. They take after Harvey.
Shouldn't you be doing someone's laundry?
Right after you redecorate my house.
(pointed at Jim Rivaldo) Sir, my girlfriends say you guys don't like women. Just asking, is there a place for us in all this, or are you scared of girls? 43.

Gentleman, we already have a tinker bell, a lotus-blossom, Jim and Dick in your three-piece suits. We need someone to manage things. A woman this time. She's the right price, and she has bigger balls than any of you.
Just give me whatever's left over in the register at the end of the day. So should I call the Chronicle about getting US an endorsement? No? OFF the group of misfits, considering the addition.

PAN OFF: a large "RICK STOKES, SUPERVISOR DISTRICT 5" pos to reveal Anne Kronenberg outside the hall handing "MILK" signs to a long line of gathering women and lesbians who filing in. Flanked by a PEEVED AID, Rick Stokes rushes out of the lecture hall and confronts Anne.
Young lady, you must be confused. This is my night, not Mr. Milk's.
(as pleasant as can be) No, sir. I'm Harvey's new campaign manager. Anne Kronenberg.

Then you should know this race is for District 5, the Castro, not for all of your lesbian... compadres-- A tough lesbian kisses Anne and stares Rick down as she h in. Rick looks uncomfortable around all these women.
I'm sorry. Are we distracting you, Mr. Stokes? I'd hate to screw you up on your big night. Dick runs up looking for more fliers. Taking Rick even mo off his game, Dick is flirtatious.
Hi Rick, handsome suit. Annie, do you have any more hand cards? 44.
These people are not from this area. They need to leave. Now.

Not true. Guess where we found them all, Rick? A slew of them. Way up on Valencia Street. Living right there in our district. And you see, as it turns out, Annie here is very, very popular with the ladies. Dick puts his arm around Anne. Rick is stupefied.

Dozens of supporters hold "MILK for Supervisor" signs in long line along Market St. waving to commuters. Anne walk the long line, handing out new signs to arriving voluntee Harvey is handing out FLYERS. He is exhausted, his throat RAW. The campaign is nearly over. A WEIRD MOMENT: A BOY walks up to Harvey and hands him a flier. ALL SOUND GOES DEAD ON THE SOUNDTRACK as HARVEY'S lock into the BOY'S EYES. Harvey reads the FLIER: aUnite and Fight for Dan White.a Harvey looks back to pat the BOY'S head, but he's gone. H looks to the sidewalk for the kid... a parent... nothing.
Harvey is still looking at the flier. Anne is leaving wit stack of SF Chronicles. Cleve comes in, pulls one off her stack, and looks for "the article."
They've accused me of many things, but never as blatant a lie as this.
First ever newspaper endorsement.
(reading the article) They endorsed you for being a good businessman? Has Scott read this? He'll piss himself.
Yeah? Go show him. (Cleve starts to go) (MORE)
Cleve, maybe you should go find a boy to celebrate with. Just in case.

I'm going to The Stud. Meet me out. Cleve goes. His energy is boundless. Harvey sits alone watching the bargoers return home through his front windo bitter-sweetness lingers. A couple waves, one shouts out:

Gonna win this time, Milk? They walk on, not waiting for an answer. Then, a drunk, cute, Latino, JACK LIRA, 25, stops. He sta in at the political ads in the window. Harvey watches him sway drunk out of his mind, waiting for him to fall. The make eye contact. Harvey smiles. Jack tries to. Harvey pi up a folding chair and walks it out to him.
(re: poster in the window) You're more handsome in the posters.
Thank you. Where do you live?

(too drunk to hear, flirting) ...Palomino's are my favorite horse. They're smart. They're fast and compact. Do you think I'm more like a Palomino or a Stallion? Jack smiles, out of his mind. Then he sits/falls down int the chair, and slides off. Harvey stands above the passed young man. A newcomer. A wounded bird. Perfect.

Completely nude, Jack plays a tantalizing game of seducti allowing Harvey to hold him, then wriggling away... Danci against Harvey then BITING his shoulder... LYING on the b then ROLLING away when Harvey tries to hold him... No TALK. No POLITICS. Just SEX. A perfect RELEASE for Harvey.
Harvey holds Jack after lovemaking. 46.
My father beat me when he found out... So I came here. I stay in this man's house. But I don't like him.
Shh, it's okay, now. No one's ever going to beat you again. A long, comforting beat between them.
I love you.
(smiles, playful) Do you even remember my name? (a beat, Jack shakes his head, he can't remember) Harvey.
I love you, Harvey.
HARVEY stands in a voting booth. He goes down the list of names. He finally punches the one next to "HARVEY MILK" District 5, and pulls the lever. The chads fall.
And for the first time in my life, it all came together... the union boys, the women, the seniors, the minorities... All of the us's showed up...

TV lights blast Castro Camera. A raucous crowd pours into streets to greet the roar of motorcycles. Anne pulls up w the Sheriff on back. Harvey is passenger on a second bike HARVEY IS VICTORIOUS! He is instantly swarmed.
The Shop is packed. It's a giant celebration party. Anne Cleve are working the door. SCOTT SMITH WATCHES FROM THE CROWD OUTSIDE THE SHOP as Rick Stokes and David Goodstein to get in.
We just want to congratulate him. 47.
I'm sorry. We're all full.
(seeing Harvey inside) Harvey! Harvey!
It's too crowded. Sorry! JACK LIRA shoves his way toward the door...
Harvey! Harvey PULLS JACK INSIDE, right past Goodstein and Stokes Harvey CATCHES A GLIMPSE OF SCOTT OUTSIDE...
Scottie--? But Scott fades into the CROWD. Harvey (with Jack at his side) is pulled back into the party.
(eyeing Jack skeptically) The new Mrs. Milk. I give it a week.
(the crowd) Harvey, is this all for you? Are you this famous?
No, darling. We do this all the time. Do you like it? Jim is calling out NAMES of the OTHER WINNERS.
Carol Ruth Silver... Gordon Lau... It's the most liberal Board in years!
What about Dan White? Did he win?
(YES)
We'll deal with him tomorrow. Harvey is DOUSED with champagne. 48. JUMP TO: Harvey is interviewed by a TV REPORTER. Jack squeezes his way under Harvey's arm and into the picture.
Does this mean, as many straights are concerned, maybe the gays are taking over San Francisco? Are you going to be a Supervisor for all the people?

I have to be. That's what I was elected for. I have to be there to open up the dialogue for the sensitivities of all people, all their problems, the problems that effect this city effect all of us. (toasts the camera) Thank you San Francisco! Thank you!
SET TO MUSIC: In his old brown suit, Harvey walks to City Hall with a crowd of supporters. The familiar faces now include Jack Lira.
On City Hall's steps, Mayor Moscone swears in HARVEY.

I, Harvey Milk, do solemnly swear that I will support and defend the Constitution of the United States and the Constitution of the State of California against all enemies, foreign and domestic; and that I will well and faithfully discharge the duties upon which I am about to enter and during such time as I hold the office of Supervisor, City and County of San Francisco. Bulbs FLASH. A light rain begins to fall. Umbrellas go up
Anita Bryant said gay people brought the drought to California. Looks to me like it's finally started raining! Cheers. Harvey is emboldened. 49.
Off a TV in Scott's NEW APARTMENT, we see a S.F. Morning featuring new Supervisors, Harvey Milk and Dan White.
This will be the first time in many years that we've seen so many new faces on the Board of Supervisors. Do you think such diversity will cripple the Board?

The name of the game on the Board is six votes to get anything passed. So, like it or not, Dan and I are now in bed together... politically speaking. THE CAMERA REVEALS SCOTT watching the program. He's been all night.

I've assured Harvey here that my brochure's comments about "social deviants" referred more to junkies than to his people. See, I'm about to have my first child. I have to make sure this city remains a decent place to raise him.
The segment over, sound assistants help Harvey and Dan re their microphones. Harvey tries to draw Dan in:
How long were you a fireman, Dan?
A couple of years.
And before that... You were a police officer? Dan studies Harvey suspiciously... What's his point?
You have something against cops?
No. They tend to have something against me. (MORE)
(seeing Dan react uncomfortably) But firefighters. Now those are true heroes... They supported me in the last campaign. I support them fully.
I appreciate it.
I meant what I said. I'd like to work together. Dan hesitantly accepts Harvey's handshake. It's a step.
(cracking a smile) I'll see you at the office, Mr. Milk.
Harvey goes through the metal detectors at the entrance a finds Cleve in a NEW SUIT waiting for the elevator.
What do you think of my new theater?
A bit over the top.
What's with the suit?
I got it from a friend. Harvey leads Cleve from the elevator to the grand stairca
When you come here, I want you to wear the tightest jeans possible. Never blend in. And no elevators. Ever. Always take the stairs, you can make such a grand entrance going up the stairs.
Harvey leads Cleve down the hall of Supervisors' offices, passing Dianne Feinstein's open door.
And street talk only around Feinstein. Shit, goddamn, fuck, (MORE)
all that. It bugs the hell out of her. They arrive at his Lead Aide's desk: it's Anne Kronenberg
Morning Annie, let's set Cleve up on mail.
Will do.
Come into my office...
Harvey walks in. Michael and Jim are in a strategy sessio
The first order of business that will come out of this office is a city wide Gay Rights Ordinance. Just like the one Anita shot down in Dade County. What do you think, Lotus Blossom?
I think it's good. Not great.
Then make it brilliant. I want Anita's attention here. In San Francisco. I want her to bring her fight to US... This Bill needs a unanimous vote. We need headlines.
Dan White won't vote for this. Harvey puts his fingers to his lips and points down the h indicating Dan is down there. Harvey whispers:
Dan's fine. He's just uneducated. We can teach him. Dan pops his head into Harvey's office.
Harvey, committee meets at 9:30. Oh, hi Michael, Jim. (to Harvey) Hey, did you get the invitation to (MORE)
my son's christening? I invited a few of the other supes as well.
I'll be there.
Great! All smiles, Dan leaves. Cleve mocks him. OFF Mike Wong's expression: THAT WAS BIZARRE.
Are you going?
Hey. I'll let him christen me, if he'll vote for my Gay Rights Ordinance. We need allies. We need everyone.

The neighborhood is booming. Storefronts and sidewalks filled. This is not the rundown Castro that Harvey moved into 3 years ago. Harvey heads home, greeted by his PROUD CONSTITUENTS. He stops at the CAMERA SHOP when he notices a BROKEN WIND near the side entrance to his apartment.
Harvey RUSHES UP THE STAIRS into his apartment and finds: JACK LIRA - Lighting a candle on the table which has been for a lovely, romantic dinner.
Jack?
Welcome home, Harvey! I hope you're hungry. I only know how to cook one thing, but I make it good.
Did you... break in?
I asked the boy downstairs to let me in...
Danny? 53.
He wouldn't let me in. So I came in this way. Your friends aren't very nice to me.
(avoiding the fight) I have a Town Hall meeting tonight, Jack.
You work too hard. I'm sorry about your window. I'll fix it tomorrow. (turning on the charm) Are you surprised?!

Jack, I have to go. I have an invitation to a party tomorrow. Lots of rich people, politicians. We could get all dressed up... Jack turns up the music, takes Harvey's hands and guides through a simple dance.
So I could be the first lady?
Uh-huh.
I watched TV here today. All day. I saw All My Children. They killed Margo. I knew it was going to happen. They try and trick you but it never works.
(enjoying this) You always see it coming?

What? Killing the blonde? Every time. I'm good with that. (gets slow, sensual) I think now the old lady is going to have an affair. Then she'll get killed or married. Always one or the other. Dead or married. Jack starts dancing with Harvey again. It's sweet, intima 54.
If I make you a key, you won't break my windows again, right?
That's right. The dance lesson is a lovely distraction. Harvey won't be going back to work tonight.

Harvey watches water pour over an INFANT BOY. He tries ha to feel comfortable, but he's the only Jew, and likely th only gay man at Dan's child's baptism. Dan looks to Harvey, the proud father. Harvey waves.
Harvey and Dan have pulled themselves away.
I'm proposing a citywide ordinance. It ensures that a person who already has a job can't be fired for their orientation.
I'm not sure my constituents would favor that. Dan looks over to his WIFE and NEWBORN SON.
Is anyone else here from the Board?
You're the only one who showed up I think.
Were you christened here?
Yes. Right here. Same Parish. My grandma immigrated here when this was an Irish Catholic city. The City of St. Francis... A lot's changed here since then.
You're more like one of us now... an outsider. 55.
You're not like most homosexuals, are you, Harvey?
Do you know a lot of "homosexuals?"
(smiles, then) Say, where do you stand on the Psychiatric Center the City's been pushing into my district?
Well, I'd have to study it...
Getting it out of my district was a key piece of my platform. It only attracts arsonist, rapists, all that, you know.
Sure, sure. A campaign promise.
A big one. (QUIET)
What do you say we watch out for each other's interests? I'd like that.
I'd like that, too, Dan. Mary Ann White approaches with their child. It's awkward, if she's walked in on something intimate.
I'm sorry. Slipped into some shop talk.
The Gay Rights Ordinance. My fault.
Seems an inappropriate subject in here don't you think?
Hey, don't knock it till you've tried it. His attempt to break the tension goes down in flames. She cracks a polite smile. They're from very different worlds 56.
Harvey is under pressure from his own advisors (Michael, Dick, Cleve) to vote against Dan's bill.
Supervisors Silver and Lau are asking you to vote to keep this Psychiatric Center in Dan's district. It'll go down 6 to 5 if you vote to get rid of it.
It's a Youth Campus, Harvey. These are kids that would be displaced from their families if it's moved.
I can't just dump Dan. The guy's got nothing going for him. No friends...
Here we go, Harvey to the rescue. Isn't it enough we have to put up with Jack?
Lay off. He registered 120 voters last week.
So do any of your volunteers, but you don't make them all first lady.
What does Dan White do for you? Really? Politically?
He intrigues me... I think he may be one of us. Everyone groans. Cleve camps it up:
Dear God, say it ain't so!
It's just a theory...
You just think he's cute. 57.
No... I know what it's like to live that life. That lie. You can see it in Dan's eyes... The fear, the pressure... Anne Kronenberg walks in. She's got that look in her eyes Something's up.
Good or Bad?

Not great. State Senator John Briggs is Anita Bryant's go-to guy in California for sure. He's filed his petition for a statewide referendum to fire all gay teachers and anyone who supports them. A pall falls over the room. This is worse than expected.
How many signatures will he need to qualify for the ballot?
Whatever. He can get them in two Sundays at church in Orange County.

(instead of fear, excitement bubbles up) This means the fight's coming here, where we can do something about it! Wichita's one thing, Kansas City. But Anita's heading for San Francisco! She's not going to know what hit her. Smile, children! This is the fight we've been waiting for.
CA State Senator, JOHN BRIGGS, 47, delivers his message t the PRESS, THE TV CREWS, AND A MASS OF PROTESTERS. HARVEY AND HIS GROUP are amongst the crowd.
My proposition promises to protect our children from these gay perverts and pedophiles who recruit our children to their deviant lifestyles, including the ones who (MORE)
do it in our public schools. It's time to root them out. In the crowd is teacher TOM AMMIANO, 36, colorful, worked
And how are you going to determine who's a homosexual?
Sir, my bill outlines procedures for identifying homosexuals.
How? Will you be sucking them off?
Sir, you can argue with me, but you cannot argue with God. It's getting ugly fast. Briggs is whisked away by TWO OFFICERS. He trips off the curb and is quickly scooped up

Dan's house is filled with RELATIVES for a birthday celebration. Dan is glued to the NEWS, watching BRIGGS. Dan's RELATIVES gather around the TV. Mary Ann puts their BABY into Dan's arms and returns to wrangling kids.

Look what happened in Germany. Now Anita Bryant already says that Jews and Muslims are going to hell, you know she's got a shopping list. We are not going to let John Briggs or Anita Bryant legislate bigotry in this city... Hold on Dan watching Harvey on TV.

Cleve and Anne sit in the entry way, Cleve in his tight j and shirt. He's very out of place amongst all the suits. Harvey walks in. Cleve and Anne rush to his side. David Goodstein and Rick Stokes turn to greet Milk.
Hello, Harvey. Running late? (Harvey doesn't stop) (MORE)
Oh Harvey... your boyfriend is in the closet.
Excuse me, David?
(QUIETLY)
The Latino, he's locked himself in the coat room... Mr. Milk, Phil Burton is here. He's likely the next Speaker of the House and a much needed ally against Prop Six. We don't need a scene.

location: UPSCALE S.F. HOUSE / COAT ROOM DOOR

text: Harvey is at the door. Jack is locked inside the room.
You're right, I know, I was late by twenty minutes. I'm sorry, Jack.
Who were you with? Scott? Some boy?
I was at work. Come out, sugar pea.
No. You embarrassed me. I didn't know anyone. These are not good people. I don't want to be here.
Then go home, Jack.
No. I'll wait for you. Go away. A tight smile from Harvey as he looks up to Cleve.
Harvey, Cleve and a dozen others are scattered about the for a meeting with the DEMOCRATIC PARTY ESTABLISHMENT. U. Congressman PHIL BURTON, 51, leans on a desk, listening.
The Briggs initiative is polling at 75 percent for approval statewide.
80 percent in other polls. Some even have us losing San Francisco. 60.
(condescending to Cleve) So it's important we not deceive people into thinking we can beat this, or we'll have riots and only increase this backlash.

Good point, David. Let's just roll right over. Make it easier for Briggs to fuck us up the ass. Rick and David are horrified. Phil Burton rises above it, passing out copies of his new Anti-Briggs Initiative flie
We're taking this very seriously in my office. We want to send one of these to every home in California. We'll need money to do that.

(reading the flier) "Proposition Six is an affront to Human Rights. An invasion of the State into the private lives of California citizens." (points to the pictures) Does it even say the word gay on this thing? Anywhere?
No Harvey, purposefully not.
With the heat bearing down on your movement right now, we think it's best to dodge the "gay" bullet. Go for the human rights angle.
People need to know who's affected. This flier needs at least one old queen on it. (a dig, to Goodstein) Why don't you volunteer for that, David?
(an olive branch) Corey Wares is an out gay-- 61.
(cutting Rick him off)
This is shit. Shit and masturbation. It's a coward's response to a dangerous threat.
(a beat, then) I think you should leave. In the face of Phil Burton, most the others seem to agree HARVEY PUTS PHIL BURTON'S FLYER IN THE FIREPLACE on his w out of the room.
Harvey knocks on the coat check door.
Jack, it's time to go. (to Cleve) Get everyone together. I want young people, women, fresh heads. Fighters and organizers, not politicians.
(as if Jack can't spell) What about, S-C-O-T-T? OFF HARVEY, knowing Scott would be an asset. Jack opens t door and grabs Harvey's hand. They go.

Harvey's clan is assembled (Jim, Dick, Mike, Cleve, Anne, Jack, Denis) along with fiery teacher Tom Amiano and MANY OTHER YOUNG ACTIVISTS. A HANDSOME PIZZA DELIVERY GUY is setting down boxes of pizzas. They're in for the night. The atmosphere is 180 degrees different from the previous stuffy meeting.

We're not interested in working with those old Democratic Party shits. THE DOOR OPENS and someone new enters. He's HOLDING THE H OF... SCOTT SMITH. They are obviously a new couple. 62. Scott and his BOYFRIEND find a place on the floor. Harvey and Scott's EYES MEET across the room.
But we can't afford infighting anymore, Cleve. We have to bring together every group. Even the old school Democrats.
(taking over) Is anybody gonna pay the pizza guy, or are we just gonna stare? People start chipping in for the HANDSOME PIZZA GUY.
If we're gonna convince the 90% to give a shit about us 10%... We have to let 'em know who we are. (his big new idea) Everybody's coming out. The entire state. No matter where they live.
"Come out, come out, wherever you are!"

I'm serious. (beat, the room gets quiet) We're going to tell everyone in the state to come out. Every gay doctor, lawyer, teacher, dog catcher... We have to leave the ghetto, let all those people out there know that they do know one of us. And if people won't step out of the closet, we open the door for them.
Jesus.
The whole state is not San Francisco.
Clearly, Scott.
It could be dangerous. There is such a thing as a right to privacy. 63.

Privacy's our enemy. You want real political power? Let's tell the truth for a change. Starting here. If there's anybody in this room, right now, who hasn't told their families, their friends, their employers... Do it. Now.
My folks know already. A beat. The room is silent. Dick looks ill.
I haven't told my father yet...
(a beat, then) People vote two to one for us if they know just one of us. (BEAT)
Cleve, show Dick where you keep your phone.
It's in the bedroom. After a moment, Dick RISES and follows Cleve out of the r People are stunned by Harvey's outrageous demand. Harvey Scott GLARING at him.
The meeting is breaking up, and Scott lets his NEW BOYFRI go ahead. Harvey ducks away from Jack and intercepts Scot
I thought you were done with politics.
Politics. Not the movement. What the hell was that in there?
The movement needs people to be up- front. Why were you fighting me?
You were the biggest closet case alive in New York. You told me and all your boyfriends to keep our (MORE)
traps shut. You were the hypocrite in there.
My parents are gone. My brother knows. I'm sure they knew.

I had to listen to your phone calls home to Mom. Hear you deny that I existed. You want to be "normal" as bad as any of us. More than any of us... Those are kids in there. You're asking them to lose their families.
If their families won't love them for who they are, who they really are, then they should lose them.
That's fucking insane.
(re: Scott's new Boyfriend) Who's he? Do you live together?
Someone I'm seeing. He's good for me. He makes me stay home at nights, out of the bars...
(quietly, so Jack doesn't hear) I miss you.
Oh, Harvey, don't... (eyeing Jack down the street) What's that about?
(calling out) Har-veyyyyy!
He needs me. Scott nods. THAT'S ALWAYS BEEN HARVEY'S ACHILLES HEAL. He walks away from Harvey, leaving him alone. 65.
Dianne bangs her gavel like a mad woman. Harvey's adamant
I have told no lies here Supervisor Milk, you will today or to Supervisor White come to order. in the past--
--I want it noted that I never promised to back moving any Mental Health Centers. I greatly respect Supervisor White, but I would like his remarks stricken.
Duly noted. We will take a recess before recording the vote. Fellow Supervisor, CAROL RUTH SILVER, leans over to Harve
Thank you, Harvey. Harvey is preoccupied with Dan approaching. He leans back
Can I have a moment with Harvey? Alone, please, Carol? She politely recognizes the tension and gets up.
Why are you turning on me like this at the last minute? What did I do?
I didn't have all the details. I'll help you craft a different version that doesn't displace any kids.
Harvey, I can't go back to my family and to my folks and to my district without this. Don't do this.
I'm getting a lot of pressure, Dan.
You strung me along. And now you're throwing me to the wolves. 66.
You only need one more vote, Dan. There are 5 other Supervisors you could convince besides me. Dan grabs Harvey. It's threatening. A new side of Dan.
I'll vote against your Queer Law. I'll get Quentin against it.
It'll still pass. You can't keep alienating yourself here, Dan.
I gave you a chance, Harvey. I really did. You blew it. You really blew it. Dan goes, the rage of a scorned adolescent under his suit
Harvey's mood has darkened as he talks into his recorder.

Across the country, a handful of city councils had passed the very first ordinances protecting gay people against discrimination. But Anita Bryant and her right wing Christian fundamentalists were creating and exploiting and fanning a backlash. Now she had referenda to repeal all of these gay rights ordinances. While we were preparing for the battle against Briggs and Prop Six, Anita Bryant was taking her show on the road... sweeping the country. Her next stop was Wichita, Kansas.
CHYRON: "Landslide: Wichita says NO to Gays." Anita talks a REPORTER. BRIGGS is among the supporters at her side.
I give thanks for all of our foot soldiers of God here in Wichita. But we must push on. Look what happened to Sodom and to the world of Noah. Onward Christian soldiers! (MORE)
(lifting her hand with
On to California!
A telephone tree MONTAGE starts with Cleve on a PAY PHONE Castro Street:
Hi. We're losing Wichita. Rally tonight. Sundown. Market and Castro. A MULTIPLYING FRAME EFFECT: the person he called calls tw others, they call four, then more and more as the tree gr

HARVEY'S POV ON: The VIOLENT DEATH THREAT LETTER AND DRAW that is still tacked up to his refrigerator. OUTSIDE: The SOUNDS of a RIOT in the making. Harvey rips down the threatening LETTER and throws it awa
Harvey BOUNDS down the stairs and into the shop. Cleve RU into the store, breathless.
They're moving. I don't know where, but...
Did Jim call the press? (shouting at Danny) Get out there with your camera!
I'm going!
Press is covered. But we don't have a permit to march.
(digs for his bullhorn) When I got Coors out of the bars, the Union gave me this. I want you to have it.
What do I do with this? 68.

You're an activist. Take it. March them. (off Cleve, unsure) March those people up to the front doors of City Hall. When it looks really bad, the city's first gay Supervisor will come out and play peacemaker. We save the city from a riot. We can turn this night into more political power for the cause.
I can't do it like you do it.
I won't always be here. Somebody else will have to take over. (looking him in the eye) I need you to be the scary one now.

A massive, angry crowd has gathered. Baby-faced Cleve tak makeshift stage. He lifts the bullhorn and with nerves, r a speech. Its pages blow about. CLEVE'S POV: Harvey watches from afar. Encouraging him.

Forty years ago tonight, the gay citizens of Germany found out they no longer had civil rights. Tomorrow morning, the gay citizens of Wichita will also awaken to find that they too have lost their civil rights. You have whistles. You use them when we have been attacked. Tonight we have been attacked. Initially Cleve is successful, but then the crowd turns, marching toward City Hall without him.
Fuck. Shit. Harvey! Cleve runs as fast as he can to cut through the crowd, to to the front. He gets on his walkie-talkie.
Get the press to the overpass! ON HARVEY: Ducking through EMPTY STREETS, trying to get A OF THE CROWD and beat them to City Hall. 69. Cleve gets to the head of the crowd.
Move... Left... Move... Left...
(charging up) What are you doing? Where's Harvey?
We're shutting down traffic, both directions. Cleve looks up at the press that's arrived on the overpas above, and turns to two HIPPIE KIDS near the front.
Disconnect the power arms! The boys climb up a trolley and knock down the power arms Sparks fly. Brakes squeal. The press snaps photos.
The angry protesters march past the large glass windows o TWIN PEAKS bar. Unlike the Dade County march, the bar is empty. The patrons are already in the streets.

Harvey RACES to his office. He stops at a mirror to straighten his tie and collect himself. OUTSIDE: The SOUND of the ANGRY MOB on City Hall's front steps. "Civil Rights or Civil War!" Someone THROWS A ROCK the City Hall doors. Harvey rushes out the front doors, pushing past the polic greet THE MOB on City Hall's front steps. Through the gla doors we see Cleve rush up and hand Harvey his bullhorn:

Hello. My name is Harvey Milk, and I want to recruit you. (AN ENORMOUS CHEER rises) I want to recruit you for the fight to preserve our democracy against the Anita Bryants and John Briggs who are trying to legalize bigotry! We have a choice to make. The fight is at our doors. We must either go back in the closet and shut it tight, or fight... History shows (MORE)
that if we continue to fight, we... will... win.
Jim, Dick, Anne, Michael, Frank and Cleve are all in the office. The FRONT PAGE of the Examiner features a PICTURE CLEVE AND HARVEY ARM IN ARM on City Hall's steps. Cleve i jazzed. Harvey stews.
They're calling it a "successful mediation." You're a God damn hero. Fuck. It came this close to a riot.
Lose the note cards next time. Your job is just to say into that bullhorn what they're all feeling.
You're just jealous it wasn't you out there.

We're losing Prop Six by 60% and you're over there celebrating a riot. I need more visibility... (the real problem:) If we're going to beat this thing, we have to get Briggs to acknowledge us. Harvey steps away, hot, pensive. Anne gets quiet.
Every paper's calling Prop Six the main event now. We lose this, we'll have anti-gay laws in all fifty states, and Briggs won't return our calls for a public debate.
He's ignoring us to death.
(steaming back in) We need something populist. What's the number one complaint about city life?
The piss smell in the Tenderloin. 71.
Close.
Dog shit.
If you cleaned up all the dog shit in the city, you could be elected Mayor.
"Mayor Milk."
I like it.
Cleve searches frantically for something... He SEES a pil DOG POOP. He scoops it up and runs it back to City Hall's front lawn and plants it in the grass.
IN THE VERY SAME SPOT CLEVE JUST WAS: Harvey with a clump REPORTERS, a red and white "No on 6" button pinned to his lapel (HENCEFORTH, IT'S A FIXTURE).

Dog mess is a hazard, and on top of that, it's disgusting. Under the ordinance, dog owners that don't clean up can be fined. This really is the bottom line! He smiles at his own joke, punctuating it by "accidentall stepping in Cleve's well-placed dog shit. A BIG grin. BUL FLASH. These flashes transition into:
HARVEY STUDIES HIS OWN PHOTO on the FRONT PAGE of the Chronicle, making his announcement about dog poop. The SUPERVISORS are assembled for a vote. The CLERK, 60, wraps up his roll call
Supervisor Lau?
Aye. 72.
Lau, Aye. Supervisor Silver?
Aye.
Silver, Aye. Supervisor White?
No.
White, No. Madam President, I have ten ayes and one no. Dianne Feinstein BANGS HER GAVEL down hard.
The San Francisco Gay Rights Ordinance sponsored by Supervisors Milk and Silver is passed.
Harvey locks onto Dan White. Dan makes eye contact. Harve turns his attention to the chamber audience's applause.
A gaggle of press has congregated. Mayor Moscone and Harv walk into the office keeping their conversation private.
I can't get my stories on page ten, you're getting page one?
Doggy-doo's a real problem, George. With a shit eating grin, Harvey offers up a powder blue p

Powder blue to sign they city's first Gay Rights law... George, we need your help with Briggs... The gay community will have your back from now on. On all issues. I hope you'll have ours. A beat between them. An alliance is forming. The Mayor si behind his desk and turns to the press with Harvey's pen. 73.

Good morning, everyone... I don't do this enough, taking swift and unambiguous action on a substantive move for civil rights. Moscone signs the law with the powder blue pen. Harvey le over him. THE PRESS CAPTURES THE MOMENT.
Dan sits at his desk, agitated. DAN'S POV: The FRONT PAGE the Examiner featuring MOSCONE AND HARVEY. Harvey comes to the door.
What are you working on, Dan?
If you have something to discuss, you can have your aide make an appointment with my aide.
Listen, I know you're disappointed about the Psychiatric Center... What else do you have coming up?
Now you need something from me. You want my me to join in with the Queers on this Prop Six business?
We prefer the word "gay," Dan. Just as I'm sure you prefer the word, "Irish-American" to "Mick."
Harvey, our society can't exist without the family, without the church.
We're not against those things.
You're not? Can two men reproduce?
(a smile) No. But, we keep trying! (SERIOUSLY) (MORE)
C'mon, Dan. You're channeling Anita and Briggs... we can work together. On something...
Okay. You introduce an initiative for Supervisor pay raises.
(anything but that) It's a bad time politically. I have an election next year.

You asked for something. Introduce pay raises. I can't take care of my family on our salaries. You don't have that problem, do you? Dan's AIDE steps into the doorway. She seems surprised to Harvey in Dan's office.
Mr. Milk, You'll excuse me, I have a development meeting. Dan goes.

A crowd sings aHappy Birthday.a One after another, Harvey guests throw CREAM PIES in his face. RICK AND DAVID GOODS INCLUDED. A PEACE OFFERING. Harvey wipes pie from his eye In the B.G. the black drag queen sensation, SYLVESTER, br into his top 10 anthem, "You Make Me Feel." It's a who's of San Francisco's political elite. Jack scoots up to Har
What's wrong, Taco Bell?
Anne and Cleve tried to cut me out of your table. You should fire them.
I'll take it under consideration. Why don't you get us a drink? A kiss and Jack heads to the bar. Scott approaches.
Don't let Cezar Chavez hear you calling him Taco Bell. 75.
He's getting better. He's enrolling in classes on Monday. Scott wipes PIE CREAM from Harvey's jacket.
I remember when your birthdays were a bit less... lavish. More intimate.
Who invited you? Anne?
My boyfriend got an invitation. I was his "plus one."
Congratulations. It was a tough ticket to get.
Congratulations to you. Looks like you're part of the Machine now. (Harvey looks away, toward Jack) You can do better.
