When I come home to Jack, I don't have to talk politics or talk intelligently. Or even talk. (SELF-DEPRECATING)
And where's an old man like me going to get such a good looking young man, right?
You're not so old. You look handsome... Happy 48th. Looks like you're gonna make it to fifty after- all, Mr. Milk. Scott gives Harvey a BIRTHDAY KISS.
Harvey, still wearing cream pie remnants on his jacket, w for Jack to come out of the rest room. Harvey's one of th last guests to leave. WAITERS are clearing tables.

APPROACHES, footsteps ECHOING on the marble floor. Harvey braces himself. 76. Emerging from the shadows: DAN WHITE. He approaches Harve with a bottle of Chivas. Dan is SUPER-FRIENDLY, as if nothing unpleasant has ever happened between them.
Sorry I missed the party, Harv...
No problem, Dan. Good to see you.
Dog poop?
Yeah.
It's good! It's a good one.
Thanks. But it's a real problem.
Oh, yeah. I mean, God knows how many problems it causes. All kinds of diseases, birth defects probably, I mean, stuff you can't even... (drifting off, drunkenly) Hey, I got you a little something.
You didn't have to--
(at the same time) You didn't have to-- (LAUGHING)

Why do people always say that? "You didn't have to?" I mean, of course, right? But, that's what they always say. They always say things like that... Dan's attempts to be witty and erudite (like Harvey) only leave him confused and tongue tied. Harvey HAS NO IDEA why Dan is here.
Are you okay, Dan? 77.

Oh, what? Yeah, sure. Harvey, I just... I just want to say... Happy Birthday. Dan PUTS HIS ARMS AROUND HARVEY for a sort-of macho but really weird birthday hug. Harvey stiffens, it's such a peculiar moment. Dan steps back, looks him over.
I've really learned a lot from watching you, Harvey.
I doubt that.
No, I have. You gotta get out there. Get noticed. That's how it works. But, you have an issue. That's your advantage.

It's more than an issue, Dan. (a beat, one last try to get through to him) Dan. I've had four relationships in my life. Three of those four tried to kill themselves. I know it was my fault they did it. I told them to stay quiet. To hide. Most of my life I've been closeted. That's what living this life is like for most of us. The way things are... This isn't just about our jobs, or any issue, it's our lives we're fighting for. Jack emerges from the bathroom, barely together and leans Harvey. Dan steps back from Harvey and Jack, his moment alone stolen away.
I've learned a lot from you, Harvey. I'm going to get my picture in the papers, too. You'll see. I've got my own issue. That's right. Dan White's Got An Issue!

STOCK FOOTAGE: Along Market street: 375,000 people have s up for the parade, many holding signs naming their hometo Newark, San Antonio, Lincoln. 78. A MONTAGE: of the various marchers, floats, "Parents and Friends Of", high-camp drag queens, etc. Harvey sits on top of a car with a pink lei around his ne a fistful of white flowers in one hand, and in the other, hand written sign: "I'm from Woodmere, NY." To a news cam
Come out! Just come on out! DRIVING THE CAR: Anne keeps a close eye on the parade watchers. Any one of them could be an assassin.

I see naked men walking around, naked women walking around, which doesn't bother me as far as my personal standards of nudity, but it's not proper. We wouldn't allow it for any other parade in San Francisco, and it should not be allowed for the gay parade.
Just off stage. Anne hands him a typed postcard.
It came in the mail today.
"You get the first bullet the minute you stand at the microphone." (looking for a silver lining) Looks like the publicity's working.
You don't have to go up there.

It could happen any day, any night, any time... (off the ROARING CROWD that's waiting for him) The nation's eye is on us. I have to do this. JUMP TO: POV shots of cops and loners amongst the massive audience hint at Harvey's paranoia. Like diving off a cliff, Harvey launches up to the microphone. The deafening cheers surely would have drowne 79. out gunfire, but when it fades, He's standing. He deliver his impassioned call to action:

My name is Harvey Milk, and I want to recruit you. I want to recruit you for the fight to preserve your democracy. Brothers and sisters, you must come out. Come out to your parents. I know that it is hard and will hurt them but think about how they will hurt you in the voting booth! Come out to your friends, if they indeed are your friends. Come out to your neighbors, to your fellow workers. Once and for all, break down the myths, destroy the lies and distortions. For your sake. For their sake. For the sake of the youngsters who are becoming scared by the votes from Dade to Eugene. On the Statue of Liberty it says "Give me your tired, your poor, your huddled masses yearning to be free." In the Declaration of Independence it is written "All men are created equal and are endowed with certain inalienable rights." For Mr. Briggs and Mrs. Bryant and all the bigots out there, no matter how hard you try, you cannot erase those words from the Declaration of Independence. No matter how hard you try, you cannot chip those words from off the base of the Statue of Liberty. That is what America is. Love it or leave it. Wild applause. He scans the crowd as he steps off stage. bit surprised to still be alive. Cleve grabs him.
The Mayor says Briggs is on his way here. He could intercept him for us. We could get him face to face. He couldn't ignore us anymore.
Get the press.

location: LIMOUSINE / 5 BLOCKS FROM THE FREEDOM DAY PARADE

text: John Briggs rides in a limo watching the afreaks" outside he nears the Parade Stages his POLICE ESCORTS take an unplanned turn. He leans forward. 80.
The parade is the other direction.
They're taking us another way, Sir.
The limo pulls in. Briggs cautiously steps out. Greeting are Moscone, the POLICE CHIEF, 25 SFPD officers, a gaggle press, and Harvey Milk. It's a showdown... HIGH NOON.
I have a right to be here, Mr. Mayor.

I'm afraid it's not in the interest of your safety, or my public's safety to let you into that parade grounds. Finally face to face, Harvey extends his hand. Its a show the FLASHING CAMERAS. Briggs is clearly uncomfortable.
Hi, I'm Harvey Milk. It's quite an honor to meet you, Mr. Briggs.
I'm aware. Sad you're too afraid to fight this out in public, Mr. Milk.
No sir. I would love to have a public debate. I'm very interested in the details of your argument.
You know the details. As do the people. Look at the votes across this nation. The "public" is with me.

Yes sir, today they are. But with my City's Mayor and the San Francisco press as my witnesses, I'm challenging you to a public debate. John nods, stiff. He can no longer avoid Harvey Milk. He back in his limo. 81.
Harvey sits with John Briggs at a table facing forward. W hear the cheers and jeers of the packed audience.

Senator, as a Christian it's interesting that you don't seem to understand what Christ was about. He was about accepting people and giving love, not carrying a Bible in one hand and hatred in the other... (cheers from the audience) ...Now all the gay myths have been shattered, all the fears, all the--
Not in my mind they haven't--
That's it. In your mind they haven't, and I'm wondering why--
Mr. Milk, we don't allow people who believe in practicing bestiality to teach our children, and the reason we don't is because it is illegal. But it's not illegal to be a homosexual in California.
And your law goes even further. Any school employee who even supports a gay person will be fired--
True. But, gay people don't have children of their own. If they don't recruit our children, they'd all die away. That's why they want to be teachers, to encourage our children to join them.

How do you teach homosexuality? Like French? I was born of heterosexual parents, I was taught by heterosexual teachers in a fiercely heterosexual society. So then why am I homosexual? And no offense meant, but if it were true that children mimicked their (MORE)
teachers, you'd sure have a helluva lot more nuns running around. The audience eats it up. It feel like "The Harvey Milk Sh
Briggs makes a STATEMENT to the press.
If they're going to lead such an open life of homosexuality that they want a 21-gun salute every time somebody goes by them, those people are going to be in danger of being removed their job.
Continuing on with his recorded will...

We were really genuinely frightened by Proposition Six, and with the backlash gaining strength, we were very pessimistic. We didn't think there was any chance we could beat it. What we hoped to do was to organize to the point that when we did lose, there would be a revolt... That all hell would break lose.
Harvey, pacing, decisive.

People are coming out, though. We met with groups in Bakersfield, Redding, a dozen people showed up in a library basement in Fresno asking for our support if they came out. Last Sunday, the Reverend of St. Mary's came out to his entire congregation...

We're still losing, 60 to 30. We have to take the show on the road. Call Briggs's office. Do a press release. Tell them he can pick the town, the audience, and I'll ask our supporters not to attend. 83.
Their audiences are insanely devout. We'll get killed.
Get me Orange County.
Jack is FLIPPING OUT, storming around the place.
You just have to go down to LA and guess the right things on TV and they'll pay us... You have to use your fame now while you have it. We could have nice things.
I don't have time to do game shows right now... This stops Jack cold.
You are horrible! I have worked on this surprise for you for weeks!
Are you drunk right now?
You are an ungrateful asshole!
Jack, I'll have more time soon.
You're ashamed of me!
That's not true. I think you're smart. You're capable. No matter what your family or your father said. I believe in you... We should figure out something for you to do. I could get you a job.
I'll never be good enough for you! Jack THROWS A PIECE OF POTTERY AT HARVEY. It misses, CRAS THROUGH THE WINDOW onto the street below. 84.
I'll get a broom. Harvey goes. Jack collapses into a chair.

TV CAMERAS ROLL. They've gotten their ORANGE COUNTY DEBAT BRIGGS'S SUPPORTERS jeer Harvey as he rips into their Sta Senator. Their vehemence frightens Dick in the audience. Harvey lifts a Briggs flier.
If in your statements here you say that child molestation is not an issue, why do you put out literature that hammers it home, why do you play on that myth and fear?
Same thing with VD Harvey, we put out publications about VD so you can avoid it.
(with a grin) But you've even admitted that there's more molestation in the heterosexual group! So why not get rid of the heterosexual teachers? Boos from the conservative audience.
We are not talking about homos... child molestation, the fact is, at least 95 percent of the people are heterosexual. If we took heterosexuals out AND homosexuals out, you know what--
--we'd have no teachers We'd have no teachers--
--No child molestation... So you're saying the percentage of population is equal to the percentage of child molestation?
(getting more lost) No, no, I'm not saying that at all-- 85.
That's what you just said.

No. I'm saying that we cannot prevent child molestation so let's cut our odds down and take out the homosexual group and keep in the heterosexual group-- Harvey laughs in disbelief at the asinine argument. Brigg looks down to his notes, lost. Harvey takes the opportuni to rip into the State Senator:

(directly to Briggs) --Sir, in your own drive for personal power, how many careers are you willing to see destroyed? How many lives will you destroy in your lust for power, and when will you stop? The crowd boos, rails. This isn't San Francisco, it's Ora County. In the audience, Dick Pabich sweats, taken aback the level of hatred. Harvey tries to maintain his composu
Harvey heads home from work. He starts into his store. He sees JACK LIRA'S SHADOW through the curtains upstairs, turns instead to the cafe next door.
Harvey sits down at the bar. The WAITER pours a coffee fo him. Harvey looks up to the TV. HARVEY'S POV: DAN WHITE ON TV talking to a news reporter. feels as if Dan is talking directly to Harvey.

All I'm really saying is, if we don't protect ourselves with this kind of legislation, a transvestite can show up at a public school with all the qualifications for teaching and they can't refuse to hire him. 86.
Harvey rushes from a packed session in the Supervisors' Chambers to his office. Anne is behind him. He picks up t phone. It seems urgent.
Hey Jack, what's wrong?
Nothing. I just want to know when you'll be home.
You just had them pull me out of my big vote on the dog shit ordinance. Did you do this on purpose, Jack?
It's poop, Harvey. Aren't I more important than poop?
Yes, but... I don't know when I'll be home. Maybe 6. 6:15.
Fine. 6:15. Harvey hangs up. His patience is slipping. He looks up in time to see Dan heading down the hall with his briefcase.
Harvey catches up to Dan who is on his way out.
Dan? How's the baby?
You didn't bring up Supervisor pay raises. In fact, I heard you plan to publicly oppose them.
I heard you planned to vote against them too, Dan. Were you trying to set me up?
(parrotting Harvey
(MORE)
It's not a good time for me to bring it up. Politically.
Dan, there's a vote to approve the police desegregation settlement, give me that and I'll consider backing pay raises.
(suddenly very dark) I don't trade votes... unlike you, the way I was raised, we believe in right and wrong. Moral and immoral.
Black skin and White in your police department? (Dan steams) Dan, even Ronald Reagan's come out against Proposition Six. You're looking more and more out of touch.
If I come out against Prop Six, it's only for the invasion of State's rights issue.

(smiles, trying to lighten) And the potential witch hunts against you "straight people," right? Dan tries hard to come up with a cogent response. He can' His behavior is alarming. He sets down his briefcase.
You underestimate me, Milk. You're very, very wrong about me.
I don't know what you mean. A moment. Dan is on the verge of tears, hot angry tears.
What is it, Dan? You can tell me.

You don't... You can't humiliate me. And you will not demean me. 88. Anne appears down the hall. Dan has more on his mind, but moment has passed. He picks up his briefcase and walks ou the building. Off Harvey, concerned.
Harvey walks home. A PASSERBY shouts:
You're the asshole that just passed that dog shit thing aren't you? What the hell do you have against dogs?

(with his trademark charm) Sir, blind people can't see "shit." What the heck do you have against blind people? The young folks surrounding the PASSERBY laugh and hoot a Harvey's joke. Even the harassing PASSERBY can't help but crack a grin. Harvey beams.

Opening the door, Harvey finds a trail of voter registrat cards, anti-Briggs literature, and Coors beer cans. Pushi through his fear, he carefully follows the cans and flyer the stairs and through his apartment. Odd notes are taped to the walls. They all lead to a blac velvet curtain with a note attached: "YOU'VE ALWAYS LOVED

head_text.subj: CIRCUS, HARVEY, WHAT DO YOU THINK OF MY LAST ACT

text: Harvey pulls back the curtain to find Jack's body, cold a discolored, hanging from a beam by a noose. HARVEY CAN'T MOVE. He is mesmerized... horrified. He grabs a knife and frantically tries cutting Jack down. cuts through the rope and FALLS TO THE FLOOR with the HEA BODY.
Scott arrives. Sitting very still, Harvey is being consol by Cleve and Anne. Tears in his eyes, Harvey won't look u
Harvey. Look at me. Look at me. You did everything you could.
No, I didn't. Not everything... 89.
What else could you have done?

I could have come home at six o'clock, not six-fifteen. Scott puts his arm around Harvey. Harvey buries his head. Anne helps Cleve take down Jack's many hidden notes. Clev quietly reads a prominently placed one:
"Beware. The ides. Of November."
Into the recorder as if re-living the event over again...
Jack was gone. I didn't have time to mourn... There was no choice but to keep on... to keep fighting.

location: BARNUM AND BAILEY CIRCUS / MAKE UP ROOM / S.F. -

text: Harvey sits in a make-up chair. A MAKE-UP artist is paint him up to look like a clown. Several other CITY OFFICIALS in chairs beyond him. Harvey turns to the make-up artist. With sincere enthusiasm:
Thank you for this great honor. But do you think once the magazine is done snapping pictures, maybe I could keep the suit for a while?

Still made up from head to toe as a clown, Harvey walks t streets of San Francisco. He waves, smiles, poses for pho with tourists. It's a rare moment of grace. He jumps on a trolley headed toward Castro. He instantly captures the imagination of a small GIRL wearing a knit hat.
(re: their hats) Would you like to trade with me?
No. What the heck are you?
Oh, me? I'm an elected official. I run this city. 90. He makes a show of it. She smiles. He hands her the flowe he's been holding onto all afternoon.
THIS IS THE MOMENT. Harvey watches aides on the phones co districts for voting results. Jim fills up a map on the w
San Bernadino is coming in. Not good.
Of course not. How not good?
60% for Briggs. Same in Fresno.
Dear God, little Lotus Blossom. Harvey is stunned. Other districts follow with similar results. They go up in red on the map.
Imperial is 69% "for" so far.
Put it up on the board. Harvey tries to stomach this major defeat, loss after los He starts reflexively tying his tie in a knot. Cleve come to Harvey, concerned.
The whole world is watching this. This is San Francisco we're about to lose. Are you ready?
I can have 15,000 people in an hour. But there's gonna be riots if this thing passes.
(darkens, pointed) There goddamn better be.
(stops, a beat, then:) What are you telling me? 91.

I can't say it because I'm a public official, but for God's sake, if this thing passes, fight back. Cleve is stunned, holding the weight of Harvey's words. Harvey's focus is interrupted when Anne brings him the ph
Don Amador down in LA.
(reluctantly answers) Kind of a bad time, Don.
No sir, this is Paul. Don just gave me the phone.
Paul who?
You talked to me on the phone a year or so ago. I'm from Minnesota... I'm in a wheelchair. REVEAL: The boy in his wheelchair on the other end.
(a beat to take it in, then:) I thought you were a goner, Paul.
I'm sorry. I should have called. When I read in the paper that you won the Supervisor seat, I got a friend to put me on a bus to LA.
Who did you know in Los Angeles?
Nobody. That's the uh... I just didn't want to die anymore, sir. (Harvey's at a loss for words) I met your friend Don down here. I turned 18. I voted today against Prop Six... Thank you, Mr. Milk.
No. You did this all by yourself. 92.
I don't think I'd be alive right now without you, sir. You were right about LA. It's like gay Disney World.
Then you have to see San Francisco!

Okay. I will. Don wanted me to um... congratulate you on what he says looks like a big win for us tonight. Congratulations Mr. Milk. Harvey turns back to the map. Jim Rivaldo is now coloring LA county with green. On the other end of the phone, Harv friend in LA, Don Amador, is back on the line.
It looks like we've taken LA County, Harvey. By 65%. It's huge.
I gotta go, Don. Thank you. (frantic, to the room) LA by 65% put it up! Put it up! The tone in the room is changing. Jim storms up.

The polls were off. Briggs is going down by more than 2 to 1. The only district where it's leading in San Francisco is Dan White's. Harvey takes a moment to absorb the map. Anne, Dick & Jim all the volunteers. What this apparent win means to him, his people. To Cleve:
Well crap Cleve, now what are we going to do tonight?! (re: a giant, jock strap wearing, Lady Liberty) Cover up Lady Liberty. The cameras will be coming our way.
TV cameras roll. Lady liberty is covered with a "No on Si poster. A brass band marches dramatically into the hall. Balloons fall. Harvey MOUNTS the stage to INCREDIBLE CHEE 93.

To the gay community all over this state... my message to you is... so far a lot of people joined us and rejected Proposition Six, and now we owe them something... We must destroy the myths once and for all, shatter them. We must continue to speak out... and most importantly, most importantly, every gay person must come out. (CHEERS)

Tonight... Tonight it is clear that everyone out there does know one of us. And now that they do, they see we are not sick... they can feel we are not wrong... and they know we should have a place in this great country and in this world... A message of hope has been to sent to all the young people out there... to all those afraid of this wave of hate... to all those who have lost their homes and their hometowns... tonight we know there is a place for us! My brothers and sisters... we can come home again! The crowd goes WILD. Harvey BEAMS. Moscone walks up onto stage and lifts Harvey's hand. Harvey is now a member of S.F. political elite. Cleve watches from afar as Harvey s off and disappears into the crowd.
Dan watches HARVEY'S VICTORY SPEECH on the local news.
The party behind him, Harvey scans the block. Cleve catch up, looking at Harvey, probing:
What's the matter?
You ever heard of sore losers? Well, I'm a sore winner... I thought we were goners. (HALF-JOKING)
I'd started looking forward to the riots. 94.
I told you, I don't "do" losing.
I think maybe we're best with our backs to the wall. It's too quiet. (a new idea, what's next) I think we should march on Washington D.C. next year.

Milk, you're a decent politician, a mediocre businessman, but you're a lousy gay man. (Harvey knows what he's getting at) Take some time off. Fifty's right around the corner. (a devilish grin) Nobody will want you after that... I can handle D.C.
(smiles, incredulous) The people voted for us, Cleve Jones.
They did. There's nowhere to march tonight, Mr. Harvey Milk. Lets go back inside. Turning back, they savor the moment, like father and son walking to Castro Camera, growing ever smaller in the fra
Dan White slides a sealed letter across a desk to an Aide It's addressed to Moscone. He seems oddly calm.
Could you give this to the Mayor for me? As soon as possible.

Harvey walks down the hallway to his office, a spring in step. There are nods, hellos if not outright deference fr most passersby. His newfound political muscle is evident. He comes face to face with Dan White.
Morning, Dan. 95.
I just resigned. Congratulations. I'm sure you're pleased. Harvey doesn't know what to say. Dan's right, it does mak him happy. But it's not that simple.
You'll be the next President of the Board.

I'm sure we could work together-- Dan walks away from Harvey. He doesn't want to hear anyth Harvey has to say. Harvey watches as Dan is met in the hallway by an OFFICER from the POLICE OFFICERS ASSOCIATION.
Hey, Dan. Just got word. Can we talk to you for a minute?
Sure... Dan heads for his office.

Downstairs. The Association meeting room... Harvey watches as Dan follows the officer down the stairs an ASSOCIATION MEETING ROOM on the next floor. When the D OPENS, Harvey sees SEVERAL REPRESENTATIVES from the Polic Department wearing somber expressions. It looks as if Dan is about to get REAMED OUT.
ACTUAL FOOTAGE: Channel 5 reporting from Dan White's stre
Most people were surprised when Dan White quit last Friday citing financial difficulties. Now we've heard that White is asking for his Supervisor job back. But many say--
Harvey, watching on the small TV set in his office. 96.
--White gave up all of his political chits when he resigned without making any arrangements. The news story transitions in the B.G. as Harvey gets up.
The city of San Francisco is in disbelief. Four-hundred bodies have been found thus far in Jonestown, Guyana. Leader of the People's Temple, Jim Jones...

Harvey heads to Dan's office. He toys with the nameplate. Something bittersweet lingers. He walks in. HARVEY'S POV: On City Hall's lawn, Dan is with the press. looks up, seeing Harvey in his office window. They make eye contact. It bears all the awkwardness of a relationship lost.
Something's snapped. With adolescent frustration in evide Dan is with his wife, the press and a few supporters.

It was a major decision on Friday that I had to come... to arrive at. But since that time, people unknown to me, plus my family and friends, have come to me and stated that they want me to stay in office, that they support me... So I'm asking the Mayor to let me stay in office to serve the people...
Harvey is firm, his hands planted on the Mayor's desk.
He gets dragged into a closed door meeting with the Police Officers Association, and comes out demanding his job back? What do you think they promised him? Or worse, how did they threaten him? 97.
A man has the right to change his mind. Give me some peace.
How many of our propositions has Dan shut down? We could finally settle this police desegregation nonsense. Cement rent control. It's his vote on this Board that stands in our way.
I get it, Harvey. I've been lobbied all week. Enough.
Let me just remind you that you're up for re-election. If you re- appoint Dan, you lose the gay vote. They listen to me. You won't get elected dog catcher.
(stern, silent, a beat, then:) I'll make my decision on Monday. (as Harvey's on his way out, with a wry grin) You know what you sounded like just now? Boss Tweed or Mayor Daly.
(returns the smile) A "homosexual" with a bit of power... rather scary isn't it, Mr. Mayor? OFF Harvey. He's come a long way.

head_text.subj: OPERA MUSIC CROSSES THE CUT TO

text: Harvey sits in a balcony seat of the filled, darkened ope house next to Brazilian opera star BIDU SAYAO, 76. He's enraptured by a production of TOSCA. ON STAGE IT'S "O Scarpia, we shall meet before God!" Refu to be taken prisoner, Tosca jumps from the walls of the castle set to her death.
Mary Ann offers the phone to Dan. Dan takes it. 98.
(into the phone) Yes. This is Dan White.
I'm Barbra Taylor from KCBS. I'm interested in your reaction. I've received information from the Mayor's office that you won't be getting your job back.
I'm sorry. I don't know anything about that. Dan hangs up on her.
Harvey can't sleep. He dials the phone. He lets it ring a ring. Finally, a voice picks up on the other line.
Hello? REVEAL: Scott, half asleep.
Sorry to wake you up.
What's wrong?
I went to the opera tonight. Guess who my date was.
Who?
Bidu Sayao herself. She was in the first Puccini I ever saw. The crowd went wild. It was like I was young again, seeing my first live opera...
If you go to the opera again, you should call me.
Really? Scott gets out of bed, considers his words. It's intimate 99.
Yes. I'd go with you.
I'd like that. Harvey is quiet, a rare moment of reflection. An unexpect tear rolls down his cheek.
Harvey?
Look out the window, the sun's coming up.
It's late. You should get some sleep.
I don't want to miss it.
Miss what?
This. Harvey's single word answer means, "Life." OFF Harvey: Neither wants to hang up the phone.
The sun rising in his own living room, Dan White has been all night, too. The coffee table is covered with coke can and junk food wrappers.
Waiting for a MAN inside to turn away, Dan sneaks in thro a side window at City Hall. The man calls after him:
Hey, wait a minute, Mr.--
My aide was supposed to come down here and let me in the side door, but she never showed up.
And you are? 100.
I'm Dan White. City Supervisor. We follow Dan down the hall and into the grand entry-way.

Harvey walks through City Hall's METAL DETECTORS. He pick his keys from the dish and heads up the grand staircase. ships in the night, Harvey just misses Dan exiting the elevator. Dan heads into Mayor Moscone's office.
With Dianne, Harvey is thrilled, rubbing it in.
Who's it gonna be? Is he replacing Dan with that God Damned liberal lefty Don Horanzy? That'll really shake up the Board, huh?
All I know is that we're getting a new Supervisor today. If Dan shows up, just avoid him. We don't need a scene today, right Harvey?
(grins ear to ear) Heaven forbid, Dianne.

location: CITY HALL / MAYOR MOSCONE'S WAITING ROOM

text: The MAYOR'S SECRETARY sits at her desk. Shouting can be h from inside his office.
Moscone leads Dan White to the bar beside his office. Dan enraged. Moscone lights a cigarette.
You can't take this away from me! Moscone has his back turned, pouring them cocktails.
The issue is what's fair, for the people of your district. Take some time off. Spend it with your family. 101. Moscone finishes pouring two cocktails, and turns to see White brandishing his revolver.

location: CITY HALL / MAYOR MOSCONE'S WAITING ROOM

text: Moscone's Secretary, and a WAITING MAN note the THREE DUL THUDS, not so different than a backfire. The secretary lo out the window, concerned. The waiting man checks his wat
Still gripped in his hand, Moscone's cigarette burns a ho in his tie.
Dan walks past Dick Pabich, past Dianne's office. Harvey' voice can be heard down the hall. He sounds up-beat,

This time next year we're marching on Washington D.C. It'll look like Market and Castro, but with a million people. Write that down. Tell President Carter we're coming after him next. I'm going to deposit this. I'll be back in 20 minutes. Dan arrives at Harvey's office door. Harvey is with a FRI preparing to leave, surprised to see Dan in his doorway.
Say, Harve, can I see you for a minute?
Sure. Dan walks Harvey down the hall to his old office.

Harvey walks in first. Dan stays between Harvey and the d Dan closes it. Harvey smiles, sensing something is off. Dan draws his revolver. Harvey raises his hand. Dan Fires The bullet rips through Harvey's hand and down his arm.

Oh no... N-- Dan Fires again, silencing Harvey's cry for help. 102. Harvey turns away. Another bullet rips into his chest, an falls to his knees, now facing the window. He staggers to it. The moment is extended as we see Harvey's POV of the Opera House outside the window, and the Castro beyond it. HOLD ON HARVEY, gazing out at his beloved city. Dan puts his revolver to the back of Harvey's head. HE FI And just like that, Harvey falls.
Last week I got a phone call--
Harvey is still speaking into the tape recorder...

--from Altoona, Pennsylvania, and the voice was quite young, and the person said... "Thanks." You've got to elect gay people so that that young child and the thousands upon thousand like him know there's hope... hope for a better world...
Scott and Anne enter a sparsely attended memorial service Most of the seats are empty. The speaker is unfamiliar, s appointed CITY OFFICIAL.
(finally crumbling, tears roll) Where is everybody? Didn't anyone give a damn?
Harvey speaking into the tape recorder.
I ask this... If there should be an assassination, I would hope that five, ten, one hundred, a thousand would rise. I would like to see every gay lawyer, every gay architect come out--
Walking back out onto the street, Anne and Scott turn to down Market Street, the camera pans and drifts to reveal: 103.

head_text.subj: A MASSIVE CANDLELIGHT MARCH. CLEVE JONES LEADS TENS OF

text: THOUSANDS of San Franciscans of every religion, nationali sexuality, all of the familiar faces and many new ones... THEY ALL MARCH SILENTLY up Market Street to the palace Ha dreamed could be his own: City Hall.

--If a bullet should enter my brain, let that bullet destroy every closet door... And that's all. I ask for the movement to continue. Because it's not about personal gain, not about ego, not about power... it's about the "us's" out there. Not only gays, but the Blacks, the Asians, the disabled, the seniors, the us's. Without hope, the us's give up-- As the thousands of mourners arrive at City Hall, they pl their candles around the statue of Lincoln.
--I know you cannot live on hope alone, but without it, life is not worth living. So you, and you, and you...
You gotta give em' hope... you gotta give em' hope. Harvey closes his note pad, puts down his pencil, and pus stop on his recorder.
Push in on Castro Camera. The sign still in the window, "We're Very Open." FADE TO BLACK.

head_text.subj: MANSLAUGHTER, THE MINIMUM CHARGE FOR BOTH MURDERS. THE
DEFENSE ARGUED DAN WHITE'S DIET OF JUNK FOOD CREATED A
CHEMICAL IMBALANCE THAT CAUSED THE KILLINGS.
MOST VIOLENT UPRISING IN THE GAY MOVEMENT'S HISTORY.
WAS RELEASED FROM PRISON. LESS THAN TWO YEARS LATER, HE
RETURNED TO SAN FRANCISCO AND COMMITTED SUICIDE.

text: AS CREDITS ROLL: The following updates are accompanied by images of the actual people from 1977 to current day:

head_text.subj: DIRECTOR OF THE DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC HEALTH IN SAN FRANCI
OWN POLITICAL PR COMPANY OUT OF THE CASTRO. DICK PABICH
PASSED AWAY FROM AIDS RELATED COMPLICATIONS IN JANUARY 20
1987, HE CREATED "THE NAMES PROJECT" AIDS MEMORIAL QUILT
WHICH REMAINS AN INTERNATIONALLY RECOGNIZED SYMBOL FOR TH
